I do think one is bound to do the best for one\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nland and tenants, especially in these hard times.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps the \xe2\x80\x98Trumpet\xe2\x80\x99 may rouse him to make a change, and some good\r\nmay come of it all,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Rector. \xe2\x80\x9cI know I should be glad. I\r\nshould hear less grumbling when my tithe is paid. I don\xe2\x80\x99t know what I\r\nshould do if there were not a modus in Tipton.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI want him to have a proper man to look after things\xe2\x80\x94I want him to\r\ntake on Garth again,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sir James. \xe2\x80\x9cHe got rid of Garth twelve years\r\nago, and everything has been going wrong since. I think of getting\r\nGarth to manage for me\xe2\x80\x94he has made such a capital plan for my\r\nbuildings; and Lovegood is hardly up to the mark. But Garth would not\r\nundertake the Tipton estate again unless Brooke left it entirely to\r\nhim.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the right of it too,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Rector. \xe2\x80\x9cGarth is an independent\r\nfellow: an original, simple-minded fellow. One day, when he was doing\r\nsome valuation for me, he told me point-blank that clergymen seldom\r\nunderstood anything about business, and did mischief when they meddled;\r\nbut he said it as quietly and respectfully as if he had been talking to\r\nme about sailors. He would make a different parish of Tipton, if Brooke\r\nwould let him manage. I wish, by the help of the \xe2\x80\x98Trumpet,\xe2\x80\x99 you could\r\nbring that round.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf Dorothea had kept near her uncle, there would have been some\r\nchance,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sir James. \xe2\x80\x9cShe might have got some power over him in\r\ntime, and she was always uneasy about the estate. She had wonderfully\r\ngood notions about such things. But now Casaubon takes her up entirely.\r\nCelia complains a good deal. We can hardly get her to dine with us,\r\nsince he had that fit.\xe2\x80\x9d Sir James ended with a look of pitying disgust,\r\nand Mrs. Cadwallader shrugged her shoulders as much as to say that\r\n_she_ was not likely to see anything new in that direction.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoor Casaubon!\xe2\x80\x9d the Rector said. \xe2\x80\x9cThat was a nasty attack. I thought\r\nhe looked shattered the other day at the Archdeacon\xe2\x80\x99s.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn point of fact,\xe2\x80\x9d resumed Sir James, not choosing to dwell on \xe2\x80\x9cfits,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBrooke doesn\xe2\x80\x99t mean badly by his tenants or any one else, but he has\r\ngot that way of paring and clipping at expenses.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, that\xe2\x80\x99s a blessing,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Cadwallader. \xe2\x80\x9cThat helps him to\r\nfind himself in a morning. He may not know his own opinions, but he\r\ndoes know his own pocket.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t believe a man is in pocket by stinginess on his land,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nSir James.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, stinginess may be abused like other virtues: it will not do to\r\nkeep one\xe2\x80\x99s own pigs lean,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Cadwallader, who had risen to look\r\nout of the window. \xe2\x80\x9cBut talk of an independent politician and he will\r\nappear.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat! Brooke?\xe2\x80\x9d said her husband.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes. Now, you ply him with the \xe2\x80\x98Trumpet,\xe2\x80\x99 Humphrey; and I will put the\r\nleeches on him. What will you do, Sir James?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe fact is, I don\xe2\x80\x99t like to begin about it with Brooke, in our mutual\r\nposition; the whole thing is so unpleasant. I do wish people would\r\nbehave like gentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d said the good baronet, feeling that this was a\r\nsimple and comprehensive programme for social well-being.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere you all are, eh?\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Brooke, shuffling round and shaking\r\nhands. \xe2\x80\x9cI was going up to the Hall by-and-by, Chettam. But it\xe2\x80\x99s\r\npleasant to find everybody, you know. Well, what do you think of\r\nthings?\xe2\x80\x94going on a little fast! It was true enough, what Lafitte\r\nsaid\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98Since yesterday, a century has passed away:\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94they\xe2\x80\x99re in the next\r\ncentury, you know, on the other side of the water. Going on faster than\r\nwe are.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Rector, taking up the newspaper. \xe2\x80\x9cHere is the\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Trumpet\xe2\x80\x99 accusing you of lagging behind\xe2\x80\x94did you see?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEh? no,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Brooke, dropping his gloves into his hat and hastily\r\nadjusting his eye-glass. But Mr. Cadwallader kept the paper in his\r\nhand, saying, with a smile in his eyes\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLook here! all this is about a landlord not a hundred miles from\r\nMiddlemarch, who receives his own rents. They say he is the most\r\nretrogressive man in the county. I think you must have taught them that\r\nword in the \xe2\x80\x98Pioneer.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, that is Keck\xe2\x80\x94an illiterate fellow, you know. Retrogressive, now!\r\nCome, that\xe2\x80\x99s capital. He thinks it means destructive: they want to make\r\nme out a destructive, you know,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Brooke, with that\r\ncheerfulness which is usually sustained by an adversary\xe2\x80\x99s ignorance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think he knows the meaning of the word. Here is a sharp stroke or\r\ntwo. _If we had to describe a man who is retrogressive in the most evil\r\nsense of the word\xe2\x80\x94we should say, he is one who would dub himself a\r\nreformer of our constitution, while every interest for which he is\r\nimmediately responsible is going to decay: a philanthropist who cannot\r\nbear one rogue to be hanged, but does not mind five honest tenants\r\nbeing half-starved: a man who shrieks at corruption, and keeps his\r\nfarms at rack-rent: who roars himself red at rotten boroughs, and does\r\nnot mind if every field on his farms has a rotten gate: a man very\r\nopen-hearted to Leeds and Manchester, no doubt; he would give any\r\nnumber of representatives who will pay for their seats out of their own\r\npockets: what he objects to giving, is a little return on rent-days to\r\nhelp a tenant to buy stock, or an outlay on repairs to keep the weather\r\nout at a tenant\xe2\x80\x99s barn-door or make his house look a little less like\r\nan Irish cottier\xe2\x80\x99s. But we all know the wag\xe2\x80\x99s definition of a\r\nphilanthropist: a man whose charity increases directly as the square of\r\nthe distance._ And so on. All the rest is to show what sort of\r\nlegislator a philanthropist is likely to make,\xe2\x80\x9d ended the Rector,\r\nthrowing down the paper, and clasping his hands at the back of his\r\nhead, while he looked at Mr. Brooke with an air of amused neutrality.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, that\xe2\x80\x99s rather good, you know,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Brooke, taking up the\r\npaper and trying to bear the attack as easily as his neighbor did, but\r\ncoloring and smiling rather nervously; \xe2\x80\x9cthat about roaring himself red\r\nat rotten boroughs\xe2\x80\x94I never made a speech about rotten boroughs in my\r\nlife. And as to roaring myself red and that kind of thing\xe2\x80\x94these men\r\nnever understand what is good satire. Satire, you know, should be true\r\nup to a certain point. I recollect they said that in \xe2\x80\x98The Edinburgh\xe2\x80\x99\r\nsomewhere\xe2\x80\x94it must be true up to a certain point.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, that is really a hit about the gates,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sir James, anxious\r\nto tread carefully. \xe2\x80\x9cDagley complained to me the other day that he\r\nhadn\xe2\x80\x99t got a decent gate on his farm. Garth has invented a new pattern\r\nof gate\xe2\x80\x94I wish you would try it. One ought to use some of one\xe2\x80\x99s timber\r\nin that way.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou go in for fancy farming, you know, Chettam,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Brooke,\r\nappearing to glance over the columns of the \xe2\x80\x9cTrumpet.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s your\r\nhobby, and you don\xe2\x80\x99t mind the expense.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thought the most expensive hobby in the world was standing for\r\nParliament,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Cadwallader. \xe2\x80\x9cThey said the last unsuccessful\r\ncandidate at Middlemarch\xe2\x80\x94Giles, wasn\xe2\x80\x99t his name?\xe2\x80\x94spent ten thousand\r\npounds and failed because he did not bribe enough. What a bitter\r\nreflection for a man!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSomebody was saying,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Rector, laughingly, \xe2\x80\x9cthat East Retford\r\nwas nothing to Middlemarch, for bribery.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing of the kind,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Brooke. \xe2\x80\x9cThe Tories bribe, you know:\r\nHawley and his set bribe with treating, hot codlings, and that sort of\r\nthing; and they bring the voters drunk to the poll. But they are not\r\ngoing to have it their own way in future\xe2\x80\x94not in future, you know.\r\nMiddlemarch is a little backward, I admit\xe2\x80\x94the freemen are a little\r\nbackward. But we shall educate them\xe2\x80\x94we shall bring them on, you know.\r\nThe best people there are on our side.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHawley says you have men on your side who will do you harm,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked\r\nSir James. \xe2\x80\x9cHe says Bulstrode the banker will do you harm.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd that if you got pelted,\xe2\x80\x9d interposed Mrs. Cadwallader, \xe2\x80\x9chalf the\r\nrotten eggs would mean hatred of your committee-man. Good heavens!\r\nThink what it must be to be pelted for wrong opinions. And I seem to\r\nremember a story of a man they pretended to chair and let him fall into\r\na dust-heap on purpose!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPelting is nothing to their finding holes in one\xe2\x80\x99s coat,\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\nRector. \xe2\x80\x9cI confess that\xe2\x80\x99s what I should be afraid of, if we parsons had\r\nto stand at the hustings for preferment. I should be afraid of their\r\nreckoning up all my fishing days. Upon my word, I think the truth is\r\nthe hardest missile one can be pelted with.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe fact is,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sir James, \xe2\x80\x9cif a man goes into public life he must\r\nbe prepared for the consequences. He must make himself proof against\r\ncalumny.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear Chettam, that is all very fine, you know,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Brooke.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut how will you make yourself proof against calumny? You should read\r\nhistory\xe2\x80\x94look at ostracism, persecution, martyrdom, and that kind of\r\nthing. They always happen to the best men, you know. But what is that\r\nin Horace?\xe2\x80\x94_fiat justitia, ruat_ \xe2\x80\xa6 something or other.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExactly,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sir James, with a little more heat than usual. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat I\r\nmean by being proof against calumny is being able to point to the fact\r\nas a contradiction.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd it is not martyrdom to pay bills that one has run into one\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nself,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Cadwallader.\r\n\r\nBut it was Sir James\xe2\x80\x99s evident annoyance that most stirred Mr. Brooke.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you know, Chettam,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, rising, taking up his hat and\r\nleaning on his stick, \xe2\x80\x9cyou and I have a different system. You are all\r\nfor outlay with your farms. I don\xe2\x80\x99t want to make out that my system is\r\ngood under all circumstances\xe2\x80\x94under all circumstances, you know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere ought to be a new valuation made from time to time,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sir\r\nJames. \xe2\x80\x9cReturns are very well occasionally, but I like a fair\r\nvaluation. What do you say, Cadwallader?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI agree with you. If I were Brooke, I would choke the \xe2\x80\x98Trumpet\xe2\x80\x99 at\r\nonce by getting Garth to make a new valuation of the farms, and giving\r\nhim _carte blanche_ about gates and repairs: that\xe2\x80\x99s my view of the\r\npolitical situation,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Rector, broadening himself by sticking\r\nhis thumbs in his armholes, and laughing towards Mr. Brooke.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s a showy sort of thing to do, you know,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Brooke. \xe2\x80\x9cBut I\r\nshould like you to tell me of another landlord who has distressed his\r\ntenants for arrears as little as I have. I let the old tenants stay on.\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99m uncommonly easy, let me tell you, uncommonly easy. I have my own\r\nideas, and I take my stand on them, you know. A man who does that is\r\nalways charged with eccentricity, inconsistency, and that kind of\r\nthing. When I change my line of action, I shall follow my own ideas.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAfter that, Mr. Brooke remembered that there was a packet which he had\r\nomitted to send off from the Grange, and he bade everybody hurriedly\r\ngood-by.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI didn\xe2\x80\x99t want to take a liberty with Brooke,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sir James; \xe2\x80\x9cI see\r\nhe is nettled. But as to what he says about old tenants, in point of\r\nfact no new tenant would take the farms on the present terms.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have a notion that he will be brought round in time,\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\nRector. \xe2\x80\x9cBut you were pulling one way, Elinor, and we were pulling\r\nanother. You wanted to frighten him away from expense, and we want to\r\nfrighten him into it. Better let him try to be popular and see that his\r\ncharacter as a landlord stands in his way. I don\xe2\x80\x99t think it signifies\r\ntwo straws about the \xe2\x80\x98Pioneer,\xe2\x80\x99 or Ladislaw, or Brooke\xe2\x80\x99s speechifying\r\nto the Middlemarchers. But it does signify about the parishioners in\r\nTipton being comfortable.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExcuse me, it is you two who are on the wrong tack,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs.\r\nCadwallader. \xe2\x80\x9cYou should have proved to him that he loses money by bad\r\nmanagement, and then we should all have pulled together. If you put him\r\na-horseback on politics, I warn you of the consequences. It was all\r\nvery well to ride on sticks at home and call them ideas.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXXIX.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf, as I have, you also doe,\r\n    Vertue attired in woman see,\r\nAnd dare love that, and say so too,\r\n    And forget the He and She;\r\n\r\nAnd if this love, though placed so,\r\n    From prophane men you hide,\r\nWhich will no faith on this bestow,\r\n    Or, if they doe, deride:\r\n\r\nThen you have done a braver thing\r\n    Than all the Worthies did,\r\nAnd a braver thence will spring,\r\n    Which is, to keep that hid.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x94DR. DONNE.\r\n\r\n\r\nSir James Chettam\xe2\x80\x99s mind was not fruitful in devices, but his growing\r\nanxiety to \xe2\x80\x9cact on Brooke,\xe2\x80\x9d once brought close to his constant belief\r\nin Dorothea\xe2\x80\x99s capacity for influence, became formative, and issued in a\r\nlittle plan; namely, to plead Celia\xe2\x80\x99s indisposition as a reason for\r\nfetching Dorothea by herself to the Hall, and to leave her at the\r\nGrange with the carriage on the way, after making her fully aware of\r\nthe situation concerning the management of the estate.\r\n\r\nIn this way it happened that one day near four o\xe2\x80\x99clock, when Mr. Brooke\r\nand Ladislaw were seated in the library, the door opened and Mrs.\r\nCasaubon was announced.\r\n\r\nWill, the moment before, had been low in the depths of boredom, and,\r\nobliged to help Mr. Brooke in arranging \xe2\x80\x9cdocuments\xe2\x80\x9d about hanging\r\nsheep-stealers, was exemplifying the power our minds have of riding\r\nseveral horses at once by inwardly arranging measures towards getting a\r\nlodging for himself in Middlemarch and cutting short his constant\r\nresidence at the Grange; while there flitted through all these steadier\r\nimages a tickling vision of a sheep-stealing epic written with Homeric\r\nparticularity. When Mrs. Casaubon was announced he started up as from\r\nan electric shock, and felt a tingling at his finger-ends. Any one\r\nobserving him would have seen a change in his complexion, in the\r\nadjustment of his facial muscles, in the vividness of his glance, which\r\nmight have made them imagine that every molecule in his body had passed\r\nthe message of a magic touch. And so it had. For effective magic is\r\ntranscendent nature; and who shall measure the subtlety of those\r\ntouches which convey the quality of soul as well as body, and make a\r\nman\xe2\x80\x99s passion for one woman differ from his passion for another as joy\r\nin the morning light over valley and river and white mountain-top\r\ndiffers from joy among Chinese lanterns and glass panels? Will, too,\r\nwas made of very impressible stuff. The bow of a violin drawn near him\r\ncleverly, would at one stroke change the aspect of the world for him,\r\nand his point of view shifted as easily as his mood. Dorothea\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nentrance was the freshness of morning.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, my dear, this is pleasant, now,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Brooke, meeting and\r\nkissing her. \xe2\x80\x9cYou have left Casaubon with his books, I suppose. That\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nright. We must not have you getting too learned for a woman, you know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is no fear of that, uncle,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dorothea, turning to Will and\r\nshaking hands with open cheerfulness, while she made no other form of\r\ngreeting, but went on answering her uncle. \xe2\x80\x9cI am very slow. When I want\r\nto be busy with books, I am often playing truant among my thoughts. I\r\nfind it is not so easy to be learned as to plan cottages.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe seated herself beside her uncle opposite to Will, and was evidently\r\npreoccupied with something that made her almost unmindful of him. He\r\nwas ridiculously disappointed, as if he had imagined that her coming\r\nhad anything to do with him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, yes, my dear, it was quite your hobby to draw plans. But it was\r\ngood to break that off a little. Hobbies are apt to run away with us,\r\nyou know; it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t do to be run away with. We must keep the reins. I\r\nhave never let myself be run away with; I always pulled up. That is\r\nwhat I tell Ladislaw. He and I are alike, you know: he likes to go into\r\neverything. We are working at capital punishment. We shall do a great\r\ndeal together, Ladislaw and I.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dorothea, with characteristic directness, \xe2\x80\x9cSir James has\r\nbeen telling me that he is in hope of seeing a great change made soon\r\nin your management of the estate\xe2\x80\x94that you are thinking of having the\r\nfarms valued, and repairs made, and the cottages improved, so that\r\nTipton may look quite another place. Oh, how happy!\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94she went on,\r\nclasping her hands, with a return to that more childlike impetuous\r\nmanner, which had been subdued since her marriage. \xe2\x80\x9cIf I were at home\r\nstill, I should take to riding again, that I might go about with you\r\nand see all that! And you are going to engage Mr. Garth, who praised my\r\ncottages, Sir James says.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cChettam is a little hasty, my dear,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Brooke, coloring\r\nslightly; \xe2\x80\x9ca little hasty, you know. I never said I should do anything\r\nof the kind. I never said I should _not_ do it, you know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe only feels confident that you will do it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dorothea, in a\r\nvoice as clear and unhesitating as that of a young chorister chanting a\r\ncredo, \xe2\x80\x9cbecause you mean to enter Parliament as a member who cares for\r\nthe improvement of the people, and one of the first things to be made\r\nbetter is the state of the land and the laborers. Think of Kit Downes,\r\nuncle, who lives with his wife and seven children in a house with one\r\nsitting room and one bedroom hardly larger than this table!\xe2\x80\x94and those\r\npoor Dagleys, in their tumble-down farmhouse, where they live in the\r\nback kitchen and leave the other rooms to the rats! That is one reason\r\nwhy I did not like the pictures here, dear uncle\xe2\x80\x94which you think me\r\nstupid about. I used to come from the village with all that dirt and\r\ncoarse ugliness like a pain within me, and the simpering pictures in\r\nthe drawing-room seemed to me like a wicked attempt to find delight in\r\nwhat is false, while we don\xe2\x80\x99t mind how hard the truth is for the\r\nneighbors outside our walls. I think we have no right to come forward\r\nand urge wider changes for good, until we have tried to alter the evils\r\nwhich lie under our own hands.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDorothea had gathered emotion as she went on, and had forgotten\r\neverything except the relief of pouring forth her feelings, unchecked:\r\nan experience once habitual with her, but hardly ever present since her\r\nmarriage, which had been a perpetual struggle of energy with fear. For\r\nthe moment, Will\xe2\x80\x99s admiration was accompanied with a chilling sense of\r\nremoteness. A man is seldom ashamed of feeling that he cannot love a\r\nwoman so well when he sees a certain greatness in her: nature having\r\nintended greatness for men. But nature has sometimes made sad\r\noversights in carrying out her intention; as in the case of good Mr.\r\nBrooke, whose masculine consciousness was at this moment in rather a\r\nstammering condition under the eloquence of his niece. He could not\r\nimmediately find any other mode of expressing himself than that of\r\nrising, fixing his eye-glass, and fingering the papers before him. At\r\nlast he said\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is something in what you say, my dear, something in what you\r\nsay\xe2\x80\x94but not everything\xe2\x80\x94eh, Ladislaw? You and I don\xe2\x80\x99t like our pictures\r\nand statues being found fault with. Young ladies are a little ardent,\r\nyou know\xe2\x80\x94a little one-sided, my dear. Fine art, poetry, that kind of\r\nthing, elevates a nation\xe2\x80\x94_emollit mores_\xe2\x80\x94you understand a little Latin\r\nnow. But\xe2\x80\x94eh? what?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThese interrogatives were addressed to the footman who had come in to\r\nsay that the keeper had found one of Dagley\xe2\x80\x99s boys with a leveret in\r\nhis hand just killed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll come, I\xe2\x80\x99ll come. I shall let him off easily, you know,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr.\r\nBrooke aside to Dorothea, shuffling away very cheerfully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hope you feel how right this change is that I\xe2\x80\x94that Sir James wishes\r\nfor,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dorothea to Will, as soon as her uncle was gone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do, now I have heard you speak about it. I shall not forget what you\r\nhave said. But can you think of something else at this moment? I may\r\nnot have another opportunity of speaking to you about what has\r\noccurred,\xe2\x80\x9d said Will, rising with a movement of impatience, and holding\r\nthe back of his chair with both hands.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPray tell me what it is,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dorothea, anxiously, also rising and\r\ngoing to the open window, where Monk was looking in, panting and\r\nwagging his tail. She leaned her back against the window-frame, and\r\nlaid her hand on the dog\xe2\x80\x99s head; for though, as we know, she was not\r\nfond of pets that must be held in the hands or trodden on, she was\r\nalways attentive to the feelings of dogs, and very polite if she had to\r\ndecline their advances.\r\n\r\nWill followed her only with his eyes and said, \xe2\x80\x9cI presume you know that\r\nMr. Casaubon has forbidden me to go to his house.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I did not,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dorothea, after a moment\xe2\x80\x99s pause. She was\r\nevidently much moved. \xe2\x80\x9cI am very, very sorry,\xe2\x80\x9d she added, mournfully.\r\nShe was thinking of what Will had no knowledge of\xe2\x80\x94the conversation\r\nbetween her and her husband in the darkness; and she was anew smitten\r\nwith hopelessness that she could influence Mr. Casaubon\xe2\x80\x99s action. But\r\nthe marked expression of her sorrow convinced Will that it was not all\r\ngiven to him personally, and that Dorothea had not been visited by the\r\nidea that Mr. Casaubon\xe2\x80\x99s dislike and jealousy of him turned upon\r\nherself. He felt an odd mixture of delight and vexation: of delight\r\nthat he could dwell and be cherished in her thought as in a pure home,\r\nwithout suspicion and without stint\xe2\x80\x94of vexation because he was of too\r\nlittle account with her, was not formidable enough, was treated with an\r\nunhesitating benevolence which did not flatter him. But his dread of\r\nany change in Dorothea was stronger than his discontent, and he began\r\nto speak again in a tone of mere explanation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Casaubon\xe2\x80\x99s reason is, his displeasure at my taking a position here\r\nwhich he considers unsuited to my rank as his cousin. I have told him\r\nthat I cannot give way on this point. It is a little too hard on me to\r\nexpect that my course in life is to be hampered by prejudices which I\r\nthink ridiculous. Obligation may be stretched till it is no better than\r\na brand of slavery stamped on us when we were too young to know its\r\nmeaning. I would not have accepted the position if I had not meant to\r\nmake it useful and honorable. I am not bound to regard family dignity\r\nin any other light.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDorothea felt wretched. She thought her husband altogether in the\r\nwrong, on more grounds than Will had mentioned.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is better for us not to speak on the subject,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, with a\r\ntremulousness not common in her voice, \xe2\x80\x9csince you and Mr. Casaubon\r\ndisagree. You intend to remain?\xe2\x80\x9d She was looking out on the lawn, with\r\nmelancholy meditation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; but I shall hardly ever see you now,\xe2\x80\x9d said Will, in a tone of\r\nalmost boyish complaint.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dorothea, turning her eyes full upon him, \xe2\x80\x9chardly ever. But\r\nI shall hear of you. I shall know what you are doing for my uncle.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shall know hardly anything about you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Will. \xe2\x80\x9cNo one will tell\r\nme anything.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, my life is very simple,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dorothea, her lips curling with an\r\nexquisite smile, which irradiated her melancholy. \xe2\x80\x9cI am always at\r\nLowick.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is a dreadful imprisonment,\xe2\x80\x9d said Will, impetuously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, don\xe2\x80\x99t think that,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dorothea. \xe2\x80\x9cI have no longings.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe did not speak, but she replied to some change in his expression. \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nmean, for myself. Except that I should like not to have so much more\r\nthan my share without doing anything for others. But I have a belief of\r\nmy own, and it comforts me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is that?\xe2\x80\x9d said Will, rather jealous of the belief.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat by desiring what is perfectly good, even when we don\xe2\x80\x99t quite know\r\nwhat it is and cannot do what we would, we are part of the divine power\r\nagainst evil\xe2\x80\x94widening the skirts of light and making the struggle with\r\ndarkness narrower.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is a beautiful mysticism\xe2\x80\x94it is a\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPlease not to call it by any name,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dorothea, putting out her\r\nhands entreatingly. \xe2\x80\x9cYou will say it is Persian, or something else\r\ngeographical. It is my life. I have found it out, and cannot part with\r\nit. I have always been finding out my religion since I was a little\r\ngirl. I used to pray so much\xe2\x80\x94now I hardly ever pray. I try not to have\r\ndesires merely for myself, because they may not be good for others, and\r\nI have too much already. I only told you, that you might know quite\r\nwell how my days go at Lowick.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGod bless you for telling me!\xe2\x80\x9d said Will, ardently, and rather\r\nwondering at himself. They were looking at each other like two fond\r\nchildren who were talking confidentially of birds.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is _your_ religion?\xe2\x80\x9d said Dorothea. \xe2\x80\x9cI mean\xe2\x80\x94not what you know\r\nabout religion, but the belief that helps you most?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo love what is good and beautiful when I see it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Will. \xe2\x80\x9cBut I\r\nam a rebel: I don\xe2\x80\x99t feel bound, as you do, to submit to what I don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nlike.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut if you like what is good, that comes to the same thing,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nDorothea, smiling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow you are subtle,\xe2\x80\x9d said Will.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; Mr. Casaubon often says I am too subtle. I don\xe2\x80\x99t feel as if I\r\nwere subtle,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dorothea, playfully. \xe2\x80\x9cBut how long my uncle is! I\r\nmust go and look for him. I must really go on to the Hall. Celia is\r\nexpecting me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWill offered to tell Mr. Brooke, who presently came and said that he\r\nwould step into the carriage and go with Dorothea as far as Dagley\xe2\x80\x99s,\r\nto speak about the small delinquent who had been caught with the\r\nleveret. Dorothea renewed the subject of the estate as they drove\r\nalong, but Mr. Brooke, not being taken unawares, got the talk under his\r\nown control.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cChettam, now,\xe2\x80\x9d he replied; \xe2\x80\x9che finds fault with me, my dear; but I\r\nshould not preserve my game if it were not for Chettam, and he can\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nsay that that expense is for the sake of the tenants, you know. It\xe2\x80\x99s a\r\nlittle against my feeling:\xe2\x80\x94poaching, now, if you come to look into it\xe2\x80\x94I\r\nhave often thought of getting up the subject. Not long ago, Flavell,\r\nthe Methodist preacher, was brought up for knocking down a hare that\r\ncame across his path when he and his wife were walking out together. He\r\nwas pretty quick, and knocked it on the neck.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat was very brutal, I think,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dorothea.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, now, it seemed rather black to me, I confess, in a Methodist\r\npreacher, you know. And Johnson said, \xe2\x80\x98You may judge what a hypo_crite_\r\nhe is.\xe2\x80\x99 And upon my word, I thought Flavell looked very little like\r\n\xe2\x80\x98the highest style of man\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94as somebody calls the Christian\xe2\x80\x94Young, the\r\npoet Young, I think\xe2\x80\x94you know Young? Well, now, Flavell in his shabby\r\nblack gaiters, pleading that he thought the Lord had sent him and his\r\nwife a good dinner, and he had a right to knock it down, though not a\r\nmighty hunter before the Lord, as Nimrod was\xe2\x80\x94I assure you it was rather\r\ncomic: Fielding would have made something of it\xe2\x80\x94or Scott, now\xe2\x80\x94Scott\r\nmight have worked it up. But really, when I came to think of it, I\r\ncouldn\xe2\x80\x99t help liking that the fellow should have a bit of hare to say\r\ngrace over. It\xe2\x80\x99s all a matter of prejudice\xe2\x80\x94prejudice with the law on\r\nits side, you know\xe2\x80\x94about the stick and the gaiters, and so on. However,\r\nit doesn\xe2\x80\x99t do to reason about things; and law is law. But I got Johnson\r\nto be quiet, and I hushed the matter up. I doubt whether Chettam would\r\nnot have been more severe, and yet he comes down on me as if I were the\r\nhardest man in the county. But here we are at Dagley\xe2\x80\x99s.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Brooke got down at a farmyard-gate, and Dorothea drove on. It is\r\nwonderful how much uglier things will look when we only suspect that we\r\nare blamed for them. Even our own persons in the glass are apt to\r\nchange their aspect for us after we have heard some frank remark on\r\ntheir less admirable points; and on the other hand it is astonishing\r\nhow pleasantly conscience takes our encroachments on those who never\r\ncomplain or have nobody to complain for them. Dagley\xe2\x80\x99s homestead never\r\nbefore looked so dismal to Mr. Brooke as it did today, with his mind\r\nthus sore about the fault-finding of the \xe2\x80\x9cTrumpet,\xe2\x80\x9d echoed by Sir\r\nJames.\r\n\r\nIt is true that an observer, under that softening influence of the fine\r\narts which makes other people\xe2\x80\x99s hardships picturesque, might have been\r\ndelighted with this homestead called Freeman\xe2\x80\x99s End: the old house had\r\ndormer-windows in the dark red roof, two of the chimneys were choked\r\nwith ivy, the large porch was blocked up with bundles of sticks, and\r\nhalf the windows were closed with gray worm-eaten shutters about which\r\nthe jasmine-boughs grew in wild luxuriance; the mouldering garden wall\r\nwith hollyhocks peeping over it was a perfect study of highly mingled\r\nsubdued color, and there was an aged goat (kept doubtless on\r\ninteresting superstitious grounds) lying against the open back-kitchen\r\ndoor. The mossy thatch of the cow-shed, the broken gray barn-doors, the\r\npauper laborers in ragged breeches who had nearly finished unloading a\r\nwagon of corn into the barn ready for early thrashing; the scanty dairy\r\nof cows being tethered for milking and leaving one half of the shed in\r\nbrown emptiness; the very pigs and white ducks seeming to wander about\r\nthe uneven neglected yard as if in low spirits from feeding on a too\r\nmeagre quality of rinsings,\xe2\x80\x94all these objects under the quiet light of\r\na sky marbled with high clouds would have made a sort of picture which\r\nwe have all paused over as a \xe2\x80\x9ccharming bit,\xe2\x80\x9d touching other\r\nsensibilities than those which are stirred by the depression of the\r\nagricultural interest, with the sad lack of farming capital, as seen\r\nconstantly in the newspapers of that time. But these troublesome\r\nassociations were just now strongly present to Mr. Brooke, and spoiled\r\nthe scene for him. Mr. Dagley himself made a figure in the landscape,\r\ncarrying a pitchfork and wearing his milking-hat\xe2\x80\x94a very old beaver\r\nflattened in front. His coat and breeches were the best he had, and he\r\nwould not have been wearing them on this weekday occasion if he had not\r\nbeen to market and returned later than usual, having given himself the\r\nrare treat of dining at the public table of the Blue Bull. How he came\r\nto fall into this extravagance would perhaps be matter of wonderment to\r\nhimself on the morrow; but before dinner something in the state of the\r\ncountry, a slight pause in the harvest before the Far Dips were cut,\r\nthe stories about the new King and the numerous handbills on the walls,\r\nhad seemed to warrant a little recklessness. It was a maxim about\r\nMiddlemarch, and regarded as self-evident, that good meat should have\r\ngood drink, which last Dagley interpreted as plenty of table ale well\r\nfollowed up by rum-and-water. These liquors have so far truth in them\r\nthat they were not false enough to make poor Dagley seem merry: they\r\nonly made his discontent less tongue-tied than usual. He had also taken\r\ntoo much in the shape of muddy political talk, a stimulant dangerously\r\ndisturbing to his farming conservatism, which consisted in holding that\r\nwhatever is, is bad, and any change is likely to be worse. He was\r\nflushed, and his eyes had a decidedly quarrelsome stare as he stood\r\nstill grasping his pitchfork, while the landlord approached with his\r\neasy shuffling walk, one hand in his trouser-pocket and the other\r\nswinging round a thin walking-stick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDagley, my good fellow,\xe2\x80\x9d began Mr. Brooke, conscious that he was going\r\nto be very friendly about the boy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, ay, I\xe2\x80\x99m a good feller, am I? Thank ye, sir, thank ye,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nDagley, with a loud snarling irony which made Fag the sheep-dog stir\r\nfrom his seat and prick his ears; but seeing Monk enter the yard after\r\nsome outside loitering, Fag seated himself again in an attitude of\r\nobservation. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m glad to hear I\xe2\x80\x99m a good feller.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Brooke reflected that it was market-day, and that his worthy tenant\r\nhad probably been dining, but saw no reason why he should not go on,\r\nsince he could take the precaution of repeating what he had to say to\r\nMrs. Dagley.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour little lad Jacob has been caught killing a leveret, Dagley: I\r\nhave told Johnson to lock him up in the empty stable an hour or two,\r\njust to frighten him, you know. But he will be brought home by-and-by,\r\nbefore night: and you\xe2\x80\x99ll just look after him, will you, and give him a\r\nreprimand, you know?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I woon\xe2\x80\x99t: I\xe2\x80\x99ll be dee\xe2\x80\x99d if I\xe2\x80\x99ll leather my boy to please you or\r\nanybody else, not if you was twenty landlords istid o\xe2\x80\x99 one, and that a\r\nbad un.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDagley\xe2\x80\x99s words were loud enough to summon his wife to the back-kitchen\r\ndoor\xe2\x80\x94the only entrance ever used, and one always open except in bad\r\nweather\xe2\x80\x94and Mr. Brooke, saying soothingly, \xe2\x80\x9cWell, well, I\xe2\x80\x99ll speak to\r\nyour wife\xe2\x80\x94I didn\xe2\x80\x99t mean beating, you know,\xe2\x80\x9d turned to walk to the\r\nhouse. But Dagley, only the more inclined to \xe2\x80\x9chave his say\xe2\x80\x9d with a\r\ngentleman who walked away from him, followed at once, with Fag\r\nslouching at his heels and sullenly evading some small and probably\r\ncharitable advances on the part of Monk.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow do you do, Mrs. Dagley?\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Brooke, making some haste. \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\ncame to tell you about your boy: I don\xe2\x80\x99t want you to give him the\r\nstick, you know.\xe2\x80\x9d He was careful to speak quite plainly this time.\r\n\r\nOverworked Mrs. Dagley\xe2\x80\x94a thin, worn woman, from whose life pleasure had\r\nso entirely vanished that she had not even any Sunday clothes which\r\ncould give her satisfaction in preparing for church\xe2\x80\x94had already had a\r\nmisunderstanding with her husband since he had come home, and was in\r\nlow spirits, expecting the worst. But her husband was beforehand in\r\nanswering.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, nor he woon\xe2\x80\x99t hev the stick, whether you want it or no,\xe2\x80\x9d pursued\r\nDagley, throwing out his voice, as if he wanted it to hit hard. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\ngot no call to come an\xe2\x80\x99 talk about sticks o\xe2\x80\x99 these primises, as you\r\nwoon\xe2\x80\x99t give a stick tow\xe2\x80\x99rt mending. Go to Middlemarch to ax for _your_\r\ncharrickter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99d far better hold your tongue, Dagley,\xe2\x80\x9d said the wife, \xe2\x80\x9cand not\r\nkick your own trough over. When a man as is father of a family has been\r\nan\xe2\x80\x99 spent money at market and made himself the worse for liquor, he\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndone enough mischief for one day. But I should like to know what my\r\nboy\xe2\x80\x99s done, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNiver do you mind what he\xe2\x80\x99s done,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dagley, more fiercely, \xe2\x80\x9cit\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nmy business to speak, an\xe2\x80\x99 not yourn. An\xe2\x80\x99 I wull speak, too. I\xe2\x80\x99ll hev my\r\nsay\xe2\x80\x94supper or no. An\xe2\x80\x99 what I say is, as I\xe2\x80\x99ve lived upo\xe2\x80\x99 your ground\r\nfrom my father and grandfather afore me, an\xe2\x80\x99 hev dropped our money\r\ninto\xe2\x80\x99t, an\xe2\x80\x99 me an\xe2\x80\x99 my children might lie an\xe2\x80\x99 rot on the ground for\r\ntop-dressin\xe2\x80\x99 as we can\xe2\x80\x99t find the money to buy, if the King wasn\xe2\x80\x99t to\r\nput a stop.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy good fellow, you\xe2\x80\x99re drunk, you know,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Brooke,\r\nconfidentially but not judiciously. \xe2\x80\x9cAnother day, another day,\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nadded, turning as if to go.\r\n\r\nBut Dagley immediately fronted him, and Fag at his heels growled low,\r\nas his master\xe2\x80\x99s voice grew louder and more insulting, while Monk also\r\ndrew close in silent dignified watch. The laborers on the wagon were\r\npausing to listen, and it seemed wiser to be quite passive than to\r\nattempt a ridiculous flight pursued by a bawling man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m no more drunk nor you are, nor so much,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dagley. \xe2\x80\x9cI can carry\r\nmy liquor, an\xe2\x80\x99 I know what I meean. An\xe2\x80\x99 I meean as the King \xe2\x80\x99ull put a\r\nstop to \xe2\x80\x99t, for them say it as knows it, as there\xe2\x80\x99s to be a Rinform,\r\nand them landlords as never done the right thing by their tenants \xe2\x80\x99ull\r\nbe treated i\xe2\x80\x99 that way as they\xe2\x80\x99ll hev to scuttle off. An\xe2\x80\x99 there\xe2\x80\x99s them\r\ni\xe2\x80\x99 Middlemarch knows what the Rinform is\xe2\x80\x94an\xe2\x80\x99 as knows who\xe2\x80\x99ll hev to\r\nscuttle. Says they, \xe2\x80\x98I know who _your_ landlord is.\xe2\x80\x99 An\xe2\x80\x99 says I, \xe2\x80\x98I\r\nhope you\xe2\x80\x99re the better for knowin\xe2\x80\x99 him, I arn\xe2\x80\x99t.\xe2\x80\x99 Says they, \xe2\x80\x98He\xe2\x80\x99s a\r\nclose-fisted un.\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98Ay ay,\xe2\x80\x99 says I. \xe2\x80\x98He\xe2\x80\x99s a man for the Rinform,\xe2\x80\x99 says\r\nthey. That\xe2\x80\x99s what they says. An\xe2\x80\x99 I made out what the Rinform were\xe2\x80\x94an\xe2\x80\x99\r\nit were to send you an\xe2\x80\x99 your likes a-scuttlin\xe2\x80\x99 an\xe2\x80\x99 wi\xe2\x80\x99 pretty\r\nstrong-smellin\xe2\x80\x99 things too. An\xe2\x80\x99 you may do as you like now, for I\xe2\x80\x99m\r\nnone afeard on you. An\xe2\x80\x99 you\xe2\x80\x99d better let my boy aloan, an\xe2\x80\x99 look to\r\nyoursen, afore the Rinform has got upo\xe2\x80\x99 your back. That\xe2\x80\x99s what I\xe2\x80\x99n got\r\nto say,\xe2\x80\x9d concluded Mr. Dagley, striking his fork into the ground with a\r\nfirmness which proved inconvenient as he tried to draw it up again.\r\n\r\nAt this last action Monk began to bark loudly, and it was a moment for\r\nMr. Brooke to escape. He walked out of the yard as quickly as he could,\r\nin some amazement at the novelty of his situation. He had never been\r\ninsulted on his own land before, and had been inclined to regard\r\nhimself as a general favorite (we are all apt to do so, when we think\r\nof our own amiability more than of what other people are likely to want\r\nof us). When he had quarrelled with Caleb Garth twelve years before he\r\nhad thought that the tenants would be pleased at the landlord\xe2\x80\x99s taking\r\neverything into his own hands.\r\n\r\nSome who follow the narrative of his experience may wonder at the\r\nmidnight darkness of Mr. Dagley; but nothing was easier in those times\r\nthan for an hereditary farmer of his grade to be ignorant, in spite\r\nsomehow of having a rector in the twin parish who was a gentleman to\r\nthe backbone, a curate nearer at hand who preached more learnedly than\r\nthe rector, a landlord who had gone into everything, especially fine\r\nart and social improvement, and all the lights of Middlemarch only\r\nthree miles off. As to the facility with which mortals escape\r\nknowledge, try an average acquaintance in the intellectual blaze of\r\nLondon, and consider what that eligible person for a dinner-party would\r\nhave been if he had learned scant skill in \xe2\x80\x9csumming\xe2\x80\x9d from the\r\nparish-clerk of Tipton, and read a chapter in the Bible with immense\r\ndifficulty, because such names as Isaiah or Apollos remained\r\nunmanageable after twice spelling. Poor Dagley read a few verses\r\nsometimes on a Sunday evening, and the world was at least not darker to\r\nhim than it had been before. Some things he knew thoroughly, namely,\r\nthe slovenly habits of farming, and the awkwardness of weather, stock\r\nand crops, at Freeman\xe2\x80\x99s End\xe2\x80\x94so called apparently by way of sarcasm, to\r\nimply that a man was free to quit it if he chose, but that there was no\r\nearthly \xe2\x80\x9cbeyond\xe2\x80\x9d open to him.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XL.\r\n\r\nWise in his daily work was he:\r\n    To fruits of diligence,\r\nAnd not to faiths or polity,\r\n    He plied his utmost sense.\r\nThese perfect in their little parts,\r\n    Whose work is all their prize\xe2\x80\x94\r\nWithout them how could laws, or arts,\r\n    Or towered cities rise?\r\n\r\n\r\nIn watching effects, if only of an electric battery, it is often\r\nnecessary to change our place and examine a particular mixture or group\r\nat some distance from the point where the movement we are interested in\r\nwas set up. The group I am moving towards is at Caleb Garth\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nbreakfast-table in the large parlor where the maps and desk were:\r\nfather, mother, and five of the children. Mary was just now at home\r\nwaiting for a situation, while Christy, the boy next to her, was\r\ngetting cheap learning and cheap fare in Scotland, having to his\r\nfather\xe2\x80\x99s disappointment taken to books instead of that sacred calling\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cbusiness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe letters had come\xe2\x80\x94nine costly letters, for which the postman had\r\nbeen paid three and twopence, and Mr. Garth was forgetting his tea and\r\ntoast while he read his letters and laid them open one above the other,\r\nsometimes swaying his head slowly, sometimes screwing up his mouth in\r\ninward debate, but not forgetting to cut off a large red seal unbroken,\r\nwhich Letty snatched up like an eager terrier.\r\n\r\nThe talk among the rest went on unrestrainedly, for nothing disturbed\r\nCaleb\xe2\x80\x99s absorption except shaking the table when he was writing.\r\n\r\nTwo letters of the nine had been for Mary. After reading them, she had\r\npassed them to her mother, and sat playing with her tea-spoon absently,\r\ntill with a sudden recollection she returned to her sewing, which she\r\nhad kept on her lap during breakfast.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, don\xe2\x80\x99t sew, Mary!\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben, pulling her arm down. \xe2\x80\x9cMake me a\r\npeacock with this bread-crumb.\xe2\x80\x9d He had been kneading a small mass for\r\nthe purpose.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no, Mischief!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mary, good-humoredly, while she pricked his\r\nhand lightly with her needle. \xe2\x80\x9cTry and mould it yourself: you have seen\r\nme do it often enough. I must get this sewing done. It is for Rosamond\r\nVincy: she is to be married next week, and she can\xe2\x80\x99t be married without\r\nthis handkerchief.\xe2\x80\x9d Mary ended merrily, amused with the last notion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy can\xe2\x80\x99t she, Mary?\xe2\x80\x9d said Letty, seriously interested in this\r\nmystery, and pushing her head so close to her sister that Mary now\r\nturned the threatening needle towards Letty\xe2\x80\x99s nose.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause this is one of a dozen, and without it there would only be\r\neleven,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mary, with a grave air of explanation, so that Letty sank\r\nback with a sense of knowledge.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you made up your mind, my dear?\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Garth, laying the\r\nletters down.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shall go to the school at York,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mary. \xe2\x80\x9cI am less unfit to\r\nteach in a school than in a family. I like to teach classes best. And,\r\nyou see, I must teach: there is nothing else to be done.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTeaching seems to me the most delightful work in the world,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs.\r\nGarth, with a touch of rebuke in her tone. \xe2\x80\x9cI could understand your\r\nobjection to it if you had not knowledge enough, Mary, or if you\r\ndisliked children.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI suppose we never quite understand why another dislikes what we like,\r\nmother,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mary, rather curtly. \xe2\x80\x9cI am not fond of a schoolroom: I\r\nlike the outside world better. It is a very inconvenient fault of\r\nmine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt must be very stupid to be always in a girls\xe2\x80\x99 school,\xe2\x80\x9d said Alfred.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSuch a set of nincompoops, like Mrs. Ballard\xe2\x80\x99s pupils walking two and\r\ntwo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd they have no games worth playing at,\xe2\x80\x9d said Jim. \xe2\x80\x9cThey can neither\r\nthrow nor leap. I don\xe2\x80\x99t wonder at Mary\xe2\x80\x99s not liking it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is that Mary doesn\xe2\x80\x99t like, eh?\xe2\x80\x9d said the father, looking over his\r\nspectacles and pausing before he opened his next letter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBeing among a lot of nincompoop girls,\xe2\x80\x9d said Alfred.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it the situation you had heard of, Mary?\xe2\x80\x9d said Caleb, gently,\r\nlooking at his daughter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, father: the school at York. I have determined to take it. It is\r\nquite the best. Thirty-five pounds a-year, and extra pay for teaching\r\nthe smallest strummers at the piano.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoor child! I wish she could stay at home with us, Susan,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caleb,\r\nlooking plaintively at his wife.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMary would not be happy without doing her duty,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Garth,\r\nmagisterially, conscious of having done her own.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t make me happy to do such a nasty duty as that,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nAlfred\xe2\x80\x94at which Mary and her father laughed silently, but Mrs. Garth\r\nsaid, gravely\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo find a fitter word than nasty, my dear Alfred, for everything that\r\nyou think disagreeable. And suppose that Mary could help you to go to\r\nMr. Hanmer\xe2\x80\x99s with the money she gets?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat seems to me a great shame. But she\xe2\x80\x99s an old brick,\xe2\x80\x9d said Alfred,\r\nrising from his chair, and pulling Mary\xe2\x80\x99s head backward to kiss her.\r\n\r\nMary colored and laughed, but could not conceal that the tears were\r\ncoming. Caleb, looking on over his spectacles, with the angles of his\r\neyebrows falling, had an expression of mingled delight and sorrow as he\r\nreturned to the opening of his letter; and even Mrs. Garth, her lips\r\ncurling with a calm contentment, allowed that inappropriate language to\r\npass without correction, although Ben immediately took it up, and sang,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe\xe2\x80\x99s an old brick, old brick, old brick!\xe2\x80\x9d to a cantering measure,\r\nwhich he beat out with his fist on Mary\xe2\x80\x99s arm.\r\n\r\nBut Mrs. Garth\xe2\x80\x99s eyes were now drawn towards her husband, who was\r\nalready deep in the letter he was reading. His face had an expression\r\nof grave surprise, which alarmed her a little, but he did not like to\r\nbe questioned while he was reading, and she remained anxiously watching\r\ntill she saw him suddenly shaken by a little joyous laugh as he turned\r\nback to the beginning of the letter, and looking at her above his\r\nspectacles, said, in a low tone, \xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you think, Susan?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe went and stood behind him, putting her hand on his shoulder, while\r\nthey read the letter together. It was from Sir James Chettam, offering\r\nto Mr. Garth the management of the family estates at Freshitt and\r\nelsewhere, and adding that Sir James had been requested by Mr. Brooke\r\nof Tipton to ascertain whether Mr. Garth would be disposed at the same\r\ntime to resume the agency of the Tipton property. The Baronet added in\r\nvery obliging words that he himself was particularly desirous of seeing\r\nthe Freshitt and Tipton estates under the same management, and he hoped\r\nto be able to show that the double agency might be held on terms\r\nagreeable to Mr. Garth, whom he would be glad to see at the Hall at\r\ntwelve o\xe2\x80\x99clock on the following day.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe writes handsomely, doesn\xe2\x80\x99t he, Susan?\xe2\x80\x9d said Caleb, turning his eyes\r\nupward to his wife, who raised her hand from his shoulder to his ear,\r\nwhile she rested her chin on his head. \xe2\x80\x9cBrooke didn\xe2\x80\x99t like to ask me\r\nhimself, I can see,\xe2\x80\x9d he continued, laughing silently.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere is an honor to your father, children,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Garth, looking\r\nround at the five pair of eyes, all fixed on the parents. \xe2\x80\x9cHe is asked\r\nto take a post again by those who dismissed him long ago. That shows\r\nthat he did his work well, so that they feel the want of him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLike Cincinnatus\xe2\x80\x94hooray!\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben, riding on his chair, with a\r\npleasant confidence that discipline was relaxed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill they come to fetch him, mother?\xe2\x80\x9d said Letty, thinking of the\r\nMayor and Corporation in their robes.\r\n\r\nMrs. Garth patted Letty\xe2\x80\x99s head and smiled, but seeing that her husband\r\nwas gathering up his letters and likely soon to be out of reach in that\r\nsanctuary \xe2\x80\x9cbusiness,\xe2\x80\x9d she pressed his shoulder and said emphatically\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, mind you ask fair pay, Caleb.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh yes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caleb, in a deep voice of assent, as if it would be\r\nunreasonable to suppose anything else of him. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99ll come to between\r\nfour and five hundred, the two together.\xe2\x80\x9d Then with a little start of\r\nremembrance he said, \xe2\x80\x9cMary, write and give up that school. Stay and\r\nhelp your mother. I\xe2\x80\x99m as pleased as Punch, now I\xe2\x80\x99ve thought of that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNo manner could have been less like that of Punch triumphant than\r\nCaleb\xe2\x80\x99s, but his talents did not lie in finding phrases, though he was\r\nvery particular about his letter-writing, and regarded his wife as a\r\ntreasury of correct language.\r\n\r\nThere was almost an uproar among the children now, and Mary held up the\r\ncambric embroidery towards her mother entreatingly, that it might be\r\nput out of reach while the boys dragged her into a dance. Mrs. Garth,\r\nin placid joy, began to put the cups and plates together, while Caleb\r\npushing his chair from the table, as if he were going to move to the\r\ndesk, still sat holding his letters in his hand and looking on the\r\nground meditatively, stretching out the fingers of his left hand,\r\naccording to a mute language of his own. At last he said\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a thousand pities Christy didn\xe2\x80\x99t take to business, Susan. I shall\r\nwant help by-and-by. And Alfred must go off to the engineering\xe2\x80\x94I\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\nmade up my mind to that.\xe2\x80\x9d He fell into meditation and finger-rhetoric\r\nagain for a little while, and then continued: \xe2\x80\x9cI shall make Brooke have\r\nnew agreements with the tenants, and I shall draw up a rotation of\r\ncrops. And I\xe2\x80\x99ll lay a wager we can get fine bricks out of the clay at\r\nBott\xe2\x80\x99s corner. I must look into that: it would cheapen the repairs.\r\nIt\xe2\x80\x99s a fine bit of work, Susan! A man without a family would be glad to\r\ndo it for nothing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMind you don\xe2\x80\x99t, though,\xe2\x80\x9d said his wife, lifting up her finger.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no; but it\xe2\x80\x99s a fine thing to come to a man when he\xe2\x80\x99s seen into the\r\nnature of business: to have the chance of getting a bit of the country\r\ninto good fettle, as they say, and putting men into the right way with\r\ntheir farming, and getting a bit of good contriving and solid building\r\ndone\xe2\x80\x94that those who are living and those who come after will be the\r\nbetter for. I\xe2\x80\x99d sooner have it than a fortune. I hold it the most\r\nhonorable work that is.\xe2\x80\x9d Here Caleb laid down his letters, thrust his\r\nfingers between the buttons of his waistcoat, and sat upright, but\r\npresently proceeded with some awe in his voice and moving his head\r\nslowly aside\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a great gift of God, Susan.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat it is, Caleb,\xe2\x80\x9d said his wife, with answering fervor. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd it will\r\nbe a blessing to your children to have had a father who did such work:\r\na father whose good work remains though his name may be forgotten.\xe2\x80\x9d She\r\ncould not say any more to him then about the pay.\r\n\r\nIn the evening, when Caleb, rather tired with his day\xe2\x80\x99s work, was\r\nseated in silence with his pocket-book open on his knee, while Mrs.\r\nGarth and Mary were at their sewing, and Letty in a corner was\r\nwhispering a dialogue with her doll, Mr. Farebrother came up the\r\norchard walk, dividing the bright August lights and shadows with the\r\ntufted grass and the apple-tree boughs. We know that he was fond of his\r\nparishioners the Garths, and had thought Mary worth mentioning to\r\nLydgate. He used to the full the clergyman\xe2\x80\x99s privilege of disregarding\r\nthe Middlemarch discrimination of ranks, and always told his mother\r\nthat Mrs. Garth was more of a lady than any matron in the town. Still,\r\nyou see, he spent his evenings at the Vincys\xe2\x80\x99, where the matron, though\r\nless of a lady, presided over a well-lit drawing-room and whist. In\r\nthose days human intercourse was not determined solely by respect. But\r\nthe Vicar did heartily respect the Garths, and a visit from him was no\r\nsurprise to that family. Nevertheless he accounted for it even while he\r\nwas shaking hands, by saying, \xe2\x80\x9cI come as an envoy, Mrs. Garth: I have\r\nsomething to say to you and Garth on behalf of Fred Vincy. The fact is,\r\npoor fellow,\xe2\x80\x9d he continued, as he seated himself and looked round with\r\nhis bright glance at the three who were listening to him, \xe2\x80\x9che has taken\r\nme into his confidence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMary\xe2\x80\x99s heart beat rather quickly: she wondered how far Fred\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nconfidence had gone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe haven\xe2\x80\x99t seen the lad for months,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caleb. \xe2\x80\x9cI couldn\xe2\x80\x99t think\r\nwhat was become of him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe has been away on a visit,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Vicar, \xe2\x80\x9cbecause home was a\r\nlittle too hot for him, and Lydgate told his mother that the poor\r\nfellow must not begin to study yet. But yesterday he came and poured\r\nhimself out to me. I am very glad he did, because I have seen him grow\r\nup from a youngster of fourteen, and I am so much at home in the house\r\nthat the children are like nephews and nieces to me. But it is a\r\ndifficult case to advise upon. However, he has asked me to come and\r\ntell you that he is going away, and that he is so miserable about his\r\ndebt to you, and his inability to pay, that he can\xe2\x80\x99t bear to come\r\nhimself even to bid you good by.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell him it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t signify a farthing,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caleb, waving his hand.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ve had the pinch and have got over it. And now I\xe2\x80\x99m going to be as\r\nrich as a Jew.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhich means,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Garth, smiling at the Vicar, \xe2\x80\x9cthat we are\r\ngoing to have enough to bring up the boys well and to keep Mary at\r\nhome.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is the treasure-trove?\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Farebrother.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m going to be agent for two estates, Freshitt and Tipton; and\r\nperhaps for a pretty little bit of land in Lowick besides: it\xe2\x80\x99s all the\r\nsame family connection, and employment spreads like water if it\xe2\x80\x99s once\r\nset going. It makes me very happy, Mr. Farebrother\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94here Caleb threw\r\nback his head a little, and spread his arms on the elbows of his\r\nchair\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cthat I\xe2\x80\x99ve got an opportunity again with the letting of the land,\r\nand carrying out a notion or two with improvements. It\xe2\x80\x99s a most\r\nuncommonly cramping thing, as I\xe2\x80\x99ve often told Susan, to sit on\r\nhorseback and look over the hedges at the wrong thing, and not be able\r\nto put your hand to it to make it right. What people do who go into\r\npolitics I can\xe2\x80\x99t think: it drives me almost mad to see mismanagement\r\nover only a few hundred acres.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was seldom that Caleb volunteered so long a speech, but his\r\nhappiness had the effect of mountain air: his eyes were bright, and the\r\nwords came without effort.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI congratulate you heartily, Garth,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Vicar. \xe2\x80\x9cThis is the best\r\nsort of news I could have had to carry to Fred Vincy, for he dwelt a\r\ngood deal on the injury he had done you in causing you to part with\r\nmoney\xe2\x80\x94robbing you of it, he said\xe2\x80\x94which you wanted for other purposes. I\r\nwish Fred were not such an idle dog; he has some very good points, and\r\nhis father is a little hard upon him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere is he going?\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Garth, rather coldly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe means to try again for his degree, and he is going up to study\r\nbefore term. I have advised him to do that. I don\xe2\x80\x99t urge him to enter\r\nthe Church\xe2\x80\x94on the contrary. But if he will go and work so as to pass,\r\nthat will be some guarantee that he has energy and a will; and he is\r\nquite at sea; he doesn\xe2\x80\x99t know what else to do. So far he will please\r\nhis father, and I have promised in the mean time to try and reconcile\r\nVincy to his son\xe2\x80\x99s adopting some other line of life. Fred says frankly\r\nhe is not fit for a clergyman, and I would do anything I could to\r\nhinder a man from the fatal step of choosing the wrong profession. He\r\nquoted to me what you said, Miss Garth\xe2\x80\x94do you remember it?\xe2\x80\x9d (Mr.\r\nFarebrother used to say \xe2\x80\x9cMary\xe2\x80\x9d instead of \xe2\x80\x9cMiss Garth,\xe2\x80\x9d but it was part\r\nof his delicacy to treat her with the more deference because, according\r\nto Mrs. Vincy\xe2\x80\x99s phrase, she worked for her bread.)\r\n\r\nMary felt uncomfortable, but, determined to take the matter lightly,\r\nanswered at once, \xe2\x80\x9cI have said so many impertinent things to Fred\xe2\x80\x94we\r\nare such old playfellows.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou said, according to him, that he would be one of those ridiculous\r\nclergymen who help to make the whole clergy ridiculous. Really, that\r\nwas so cutting that I felt a little cut myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCaleb laughed. \xe2\x80\x9cShe gets her tongue from you, Susan,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, with\r\nsome enjoyment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot its flippancy, father,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mary, quickly, fearing that her\r\nmother would be displeased. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is rather too bad of Fred to repeat my\r\nflippant speeches to Mr. Farebrother.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was certainly a hasty speech, my dear,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Garth, with whom\r\nspeaking evil of dignities was a high misdemeanor. \xe2\x80\x9cWe should not value\r\nour Vicar the less because there was a ridiculous curate in the next\r\nparish.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s something in what she says, though,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caleb, not disposed\r\nto have Mary\xe2\x80\x99s sharpness undervalued. \xe2\x80\x9cA bad workman of any sort makes\r\nhis fellows mistrusted. Things hang together,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, looking on the\r\nfloor and moving his feet uneasily with a sense that words were\r\nscantier than thoughts.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cClearly,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Vicar, amused. \xe2\x80\x9cBy being contemptible we set men\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nminds to the tune of contempt. I certainly agree with Miss Garth\xe2\x80\x99s view\r\nof the matter, whether I am condemned by it or not. But as to Fred\r\nVincy, it is only fair he should be excused a little: old\r\nFeatherstone\xe2\x80\x99s delusive behavior did help to spoil him. There was\r\nsomething quite diabolical in not leaving him a farthing after all. But\r\nFred has the good taste not to dwell on that. And what he cares most\r\nabout is having offended you, Mrs. Garth; he supposes you will never\r\nthink well of him again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have been disappointed in Fred,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Garth, with decision.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I shall be ready to think well of him again when he gives me good\r\nreason to do so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt this point Mary went out of the room, taking Letty with her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, we must forgive young people when they\xe2\x80\x99re sorry,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caleb,\r\nwatching Mary close the door. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd as you say, Mr. Farebrother, there\r\nwas the very devil in that old man. Now Mary\xe2\x80\x99s gone out, I must tell\r\nyou a thing\xe2\x80\x94it\xe2\x80\x99s only known to Susan and me, and you\xe2\x80\x99ll not tell it\r\nagain. The old scoundrel wanted Mary to burn one of the wills the very\r\nnight he died, when she was sitting up with him by herself, and he\r\noffered her a sum of money that he had in the box by him if she would\r\ndo it. But Mary, you understand, could do no such thing\xe2\x80\x94would not be\r\nhandling his iron chest, and so on. Now, you see, the will he wanted\r\nburnt was this last, so that if Mary had done what he wanted, Fred\r\nVincy would have had ten thousand pounds. The old man did turn to him\r\nat the last. That touches poor Mary close; she couldn\xe2\x80\x99t help it\xe2\x80\x94she was\r\nin the right to do what she did, but she feels, as she says, much as if\r\nshe had knocked down somebody\xe2\x80\x99s property and broken it against her\r\nwill, when she was rightfully defending herself. I feel with her,\r\nsomehow, and if I could make any amends to the poor lad, instead of\r\nbearing him a grudge for the harm he did us, I should be glad to do it.\r\nNow, what is your opinion, sir? Susan doesn\xe2\x80\x99t agree with me; she\r\nsays\xe2\x80\x94tell what you say, Susan.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMary could not have acted otherwise, even if she had known what would\r\nbe the effect on Fred,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Garth, pausing from her work, and\r\nlooking at Mr. Farebrother.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd she was quite ignorant of it. It seems to me, a loss which falls\r\non another because we have done right is not to lie upon our\r\nconscience.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Vicar did not answer immediately, and Caleb said, \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s the\r\nfeeling. The child feels in that way, and I feel with her. You don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nmean your horse to tread on a dog when you\xe2\x80\x99re backing out of the way;\r\nbut it goes through you, when it\xe2\x80\x99s done.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am sure Mrs. Garth would agree with you there,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr.\r\nFarebrother, who for some reason seemed more inclined to ruminate than\r\nto speak. \xe2\x80\x9cOne could hardly say that the feeling you mention about Fred\r\nis wrong\xe2\x80\x94or rather, mistaken\xe2\x80\x94though no man ought to make a claim on\r\nsuch feeling.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, well,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caleb, \xe2\x80\x9cit\xe2\x80\x99s a secret. You will not tell Fred.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly not. But I shall carry the other good news\xe2\x80\x94that you can\r\nafford the loss he caused you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Farebrother left the house soon after, and seeing Mary in the\r\norchard with Letty, went to say good-by to her. They made a pretty\r\npicture in the western light which brought out the brightness of the\r\napples on the old scant-leaved boughs\xe2\x80\x94Mary in her lavender gingham and\r\nblack ribbons holding a basket, while Letty in her well-worn nankin\r\npicked up the fallen apples. If you want to know more particularly how\r\nMary looked, ten to one you will see a face like hers in the crowded\r\nstreet to-morrow, if you are there on the watch: she will not be among\r\nthose daughters of Zion who are haughty, and walk with stretched-out\r\nnecks and wanton eyes, mincing as they go: let all those pass, and fix\r\nyour eyes on some small plump brownish person of firm but quiet\r\ncarriage, who looks about her, but does not suppose that anybody is\r\nlooking at her. If she has a broad face and square brow, well-marked\r\neyebrows and curly dark hair, a certain expression of amusement in her\r\nglance which her mouth keeps the secret of, and for the rest features\r\nentirely insignificant\xe2\x80\x94take that ordinary but not disagreeable person\r\nfor a portrait of Mary Garth. If you made her smile, she would show you\r\nperfect little teeth; if you made her angry, she would not raise her\r\nvoice, but would probably say one of the bitterest things you have ever\r\ntasted the flavor of; if you did her a kindness, she would never forget\r\nit. Mary admired the keen-faced handsome little Vicar in his\r\nwell-brushed threadbare clothes more than any man she had had the\r\nopportunity of knowing. She had never heard him say a foolish thing,\r\nthough she knew that he did unwise ones; and perhaps foolish sayings\r\nwere more objectionable to her than any of Mr. Farebrother\xe2\x80\x99s unwise\r\ndoings. At least, it was remarkable that the actual imperfections of\r\nthe Vicar\xe2\x80\x99s clerical character never seemed to call forth the same\r\nscorn and dislike which she showed beforehand for the predicted\r\nimperfections of the clerical character sustained by Fred Vincy. These\r\nirregularities of judgment, I imagine, are found even in riper minds\r\nthan Mary Garth\xe2\x80\x99s: our impartiality is kept for abstract merit and\r\ndemerit, which none of us ever saw. Will any one guess towards which of\r\nthose widely different men Mary had the peculiar woman\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ntenderness?\xe2\x80\x94the one she was most inclined to be severe on, or the\r\ncontrary?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you any message for your old playfellow, Miss Garth?\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\nVicar, as he took a fragrant apple from the basket which she held\r\ntowards him, and put it in his pocket. \xe2\x80\x9cSomething to soften down that\r\nharsh judgment? I am going straight to see him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mary, shaking her head, and smiling. \xe2\x80\x9cIf I were to say that\r\nhe would not be ridiculous as a clergyman, I must say that he would be\r\nsomething worse than ridiculous. But I am very glad to hear that he is\r\ngoing away to work.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn the other hand, I am very glad to hear that _you_ are not going\r\naway to work. My mother, I am sure, will be all the happier if you will\r\ncome to see her at the vicarage: you know she is fond of having young\r\npeople to talk to, and she has a great deal to tell about old times.\r\nYou will really be doing a kindness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI should like it very much, if I may,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mary. \xe2\x80\x9cEverything seems\r\ntoo happy for me all at once. I thought it would always be part of my\r\nlife to long for home, and losing that grievance makes me feel rather\r\nempty: I suppose it served instead of sense to fill up my mind?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMay I go with you, Mary?\xe2\x80\x9d whispered Letty\xe2\x80\x94a most inconvenient child,\r\nwho listened to everything. But she was made exultant by having her\r\nchin pinched and her cheek kissed by Mr. Farebrother\xe2\x80\x94an incident which\r\nshe narrated to her mother and father.\r\n\r\nAs the Vicar walked to Lowick, any one watching him closely might have\r\nseen him twice shrug his shoulders. I think that the rare Englishmen\r\nwho have this gesture are never of the heavy type\xe2\x80\x94for fear of any\r\nlumbering instance to the contrary, I will say, hardly ever; they have\r\nusually a fine temperament and much tolerance towards the smaller\r\nerrors of men (themselves inclusive). The Vicar was holding an inward\r\ndialogue in which he told himself that there was probably something\r\nmore between Fred and Mary Garth than the regard of old playfellows,\r\nand replied with a question whether that bit of womanhood were not a\r\ngreat deal too choice for that crude young gentleman. The rejoinder to\r\nthis was the first shrug. Then he laughed at himself for being likely\r\nto have felt jealous, as if he had been a man able to marry, which,\r\nadded he, it is as clear as any balance-sheet that I am not. Whereupon\r\nfollowed the second shrug.\r\n\r\nWhat could two men, so different from each other, see in this \xe2\x80\x9cbrown\r\npatch,\xe2\x80\x9d as Mary called herself? It was certainly not her plainness that\r\nattracted them (and let all plain young ladies be warned against the\r\ndangerous encouragement given them by Society to confide in their want\r\nof beauty). A human being in this aged nation of ours is a very\r\nwonderful whole, the slow creation of long interchanging influences:\r\nand charm is a result of two such wholes, the one loving and the one\r\nloved.\r\n\r\nWhen Mr. and Mrs. Garth were sitting alone, Caleb said, \xe2\x80\x9cSusan, guess\r\nwhat I\xe2\x80\x99m thinking of.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe rotation of crops,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Garth, smiling at him, above her\r\nknitting, \xe2\x80\x9cor else the back-doors of the Tipton cottages.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caleb, gravely; \xe2\x80\x9cI am thinking that I could do a great turn\r\nfor Fred Vincy. Christy\xe2\x80\x99s gone, Alfred will be gone soon, and it will\r\nbe five years before Jim is ready to take to business. I shall want\r\nhelp, and Fred might come in and learn the nature of things and act\r\nunder me, and it might be the making of him into a useful man, if he\r\ngives up being a parson. What do you think?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think, there is hardly anything honest that his family would object\r\nto more,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Garth, decidedly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat care I about their objecting?\xe2\x80\x9d said Caleb, with a sturdiness\r\nwhich he was apt to show when he had an opinion. \xe2\x80\x9cThe lad is of age and\r\nmust get his bread. He has sense enough and quickness enough; he likes\r\nbeing on the land, and it\xe2\x80\x99s my belief that he could learn business well\r\nif he gave his mind to it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut would he? His father and mother wanted him to be a fine gentleman,\r\nand I think he has the same sort of feeling himself. They all think us\r\nbeneath them. And if the proposal came from you, I am sure Mrs. Vincy\r\nwould say that we wanted Fred for Mary.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLife is a poor tale, if it is to be settled by nonsense of that sort,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid Caleb, with disgust.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, but there is a certain pride which is proper, Caleb.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI call it improper pride to let fools\xe2\x80\x99 notions hinder you from doing a\r\ngood action. There\xe2\x80\x99s no sort of work,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caleb, with fervor, putting\r\nout his hand and moving it up and down to mark his emphasis, \xe2\x80\x9cthat\r\ncould ever be done well, if you minded what fools say. You must have it\r\ninside you that your plan is right, and that plan you must follow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will not oppose any plan you have set your mind on, Caleb,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nMrs. Garth, who was a firm woman, but knew that there were some points\r\non which her mild husband was yet firmer. \xe2\x80\x9cStill, it seems to be fixed\r\nthat Fred is to go back to college: will it not be better to wait and\r\nsee what he will choose to do after that? It is not easy to keep people\r\nagainst their will. And you are not yet quite sure enough of your own\r\nposition, or what you will want.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, it may be better to wait a bit. But as to my getting plenty of\r\nwork for two, I\xe2\x80\x99m pretty sure of that. I\xe2\x80\x99ve always had my hands full\r\nwith scattered things, and there\xe2\x80\x99s always something fresh turning up.\r\nWhy, only yesterday\xe2\x80\x94bless me, I don\xe2\x80\x99t think I told you!\xe2\x80\x94it was rather\r\nodd that two men should have been at me on different sides to do the\r\nsame bit of valuing. And who do you think they were?\xe2\x80\x9d said Caleb,\r\ntaking a pinch of snuff and holding it up between his fingers, as if it\r\nwere a part of his exposition. He was fond of a pinch when it occurred\r\nto him, but he usually forgot that this indulgence was at his command.\r\n\r\nHis wife held down her knitting and looked attentive.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, that Rigg, or Rigg Featherstone, was one. But Bulstrode was\r\nbefore him, so I\xe2\x80\x99m going to do it for Bulstrode. Whether it\xe2\x80\x99s mortgage\r\nor purchase they\xe2\x80\x99re going for, I can\xe2\x80\x99t tell yet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan that man be going to sell the land just left him\xe2\x80\x94which he has\r\ntaken the name for?\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Garth.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDeuce knows,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caleb, who never referred the knowledge of\r\ndiscreditable doings to any higher power than the deuce. \xe2\x80\x9cBut Bulstrode\r\nhas long been wanting to get a handsome bit of land under his\r\nfingers\xe2\x80\x94that I know. And it\xe2\x80\x99s a difficult matter to get, in this part\r\nof the country.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCaleb scattered his snuff carefully instead of taking it, and then\r\nadded, \xe2\x80\x9cThe ins and outs of things are curious. Here is the land\r\nthey\xe2\x80\x99ve been all along expecting for Fred, which it seems the old man\r\nnever meant to leave him a foot of, but left it to this side-slip of a\r\nson that he kept in the dark, and thought of his sticking there and\r\nvexing everybody as well as he could have vexed \xe2\x80\x99em himself if he could\r\nhave kept alive. I say, it would be curious if it got into Bulstrode\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhands after all. The old man hated him, and never would bank with him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat reason could the miserable creature have for hating a man whom he\r\nhad nothing to do with?\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Garth.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPooh! where\xe2\x80\x99s the use of asking for such fellows\xe2\x80\x99 reasons?
