He looked at the released head, and said, \xe2\x80\x9cAh!\xe2\x80\x9d in a tone of\r\nsatisfaction.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was I who did it, James,\xe2\x80\x9d said Celia. \xe2\x80\x9cDodo need not make such a\r\nslavery of her mourning; she need not wear that cap any more among her\r\nfriends.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear Celia,\xe2\x80\x9d said Lady Chettam, \xe2\x80\x9ca widow must wear her mourning at\r\nleast a year.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot if she marries again before the end of it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Cadwallader,\r\nwho had some pleasure in startling her good friend the Dowager. Sir\r\nJames was annoyed, and leaned forward to play with Celia\xe2\x80\x99s Maltese dog.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is very rare, I hope,\xe2\x80\x9d said Lady Chettam, in a tone intended to\r\nguard against such events. \xe2\x80\x9cNo friend of ours ever committed herself in\r\nthat way except Mrs. Beevor, and it was very painful to Lord Grinsell\r\nwhen she did so. Her first husband was objectionable, which made it the\r\ngreater wonder. And severely she was punished for it. They said Captain\r\nBeevor dragged her about by the hair, and held up loaded pistols at\r\nher.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, if she took the wrong man!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Cadwallader, who was in a\r\ndecidedly wicked mood. \xe2\x80\x9cMarriage is always bad then, first or second.\r\nPriority is a poor recommendation in a husband if he has got no other.\r\nI would rather have a good second husband than an indifferent first.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear, your clever tongue runs away with you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Lady Chettam. \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nam sure you would be the last woman to marry again prematurely, if our\r\ndear Rector were taken away.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I make no vows; it might be a necessary economy. It is lawful to\r\nmarry again, I suppose; else we might as well be Hindoos instead of\r\nChristians. Of course if a woman accepts the wrong man, she must take\r\nthe consequences, and one who does it twice over deserves her fate. But\r\nif she can marry blood, beauty, and bravery\xe2\x80\x94the sooner the better.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think the subject of our conversation is very ill-chosen,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sir\r\nJames, with a look of disgust. \xe2\x80\x9cSuppose we change it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot on my account, Sir James,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dorothea, determined not to lose\r\nthe opportunity of freeing herself from certain oblique references to\r\nexcellent matches. \xe2\x80\x9cIf you are speaking on my behalf, I can assure you\r\nthat no question can be more indifferent and impersonal to me than\r\nsecond marriage. It is no more to me than if you talked of women going\r\nfox-hunting: whether it is admirable in them or not, I shall not follow\r\nthem. Pray let Mrs. Cadwallader amuse herself on that subject as much\r\nas on any other.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear Mrs. Casaubon,\xe2\x80\x9d said Lady Chettam, in her stateliest way, \xe2\x80\x9cyou\r\ndo not, I hope, think there was any allusion to you in my mentioning\r\nMrs. Beevor. It was only an instance that occurred to me. She was\r\nstep-daughter to Lord Grinsell: he married Mrs. Teveroy for his second\r\nwife. There could be no possible allusion to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh no,\xe2\x80\x9d said Celia. \xe2\x80\x9cNobody chose the subject; it all came out of\r\nDodo\xe2\x80\x99s cap. Mrs. Cadwallader only said what was quite true. A woman\r\ncould not be married in a widow\xe2\x80\x99s cap, James.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHush, my dear!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Cadwallader. \xe2\x80\x9cI will not offend again. I\r\nwill not even refer to Dido or Zenobia. Only what are we to talk about?\r\nI, for my part, object to the discussion of Human Nature, because that\r\nis the nature of rectors\xe2\x80\x99 wives.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nLater in the evening, after Mrs. Cadwallader was gone, Celia said\r\nprivately to Dorothea, \xe2\x80\x9cReally, Dodo, taking your cap off made you like\r\nyourself again in more ways than one. You spoke up just as you used to\r\ndo, when anything was said to displease you. But I could hardly make\r\nout whether it was James that you thought wrong, or Mrs. Cadwallader.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNeither,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dorothea. \xe2\x80\x9cJames spoke out of delicacy to me, but he\r\nwas mistaken in supposing that I minded what Mrs. Cadwallader said. I\r\nshould only mind if there were a law obliging me to take any piece of\r\nblood and beauty that she or anybody else recommended.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you know, Dodo, if you ever did marry, it would be all the better\r\nto have blood and beauty,\xe2\x80\x9d said Celia, reflecting that Mr. Casaubon had\r\nnot been richly endowed with those gifts, and that it would be well to\r\ncaution Dorothea in time.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t be anxious, Kitty; I have quite other thoughts about my life. I\r\nshall never marry again,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dorothea, touching her sister\xe2\x80\x99s chin,\r\nand looking at her with indulgent affection. Celia was nursing her\r\nbaby, and Dorothea had come to say good-night to her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReally\xe2\x80\x94quite?\xe2\x80\x9d said Celia. \xe2\x80\x9cNot anybody at all\xe2\x80\x94if he were very\r\nwonderful indeed?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDorothea shook her head slowly. \xe2\x80\x9cNot anybody at all. I have delightful\r\nplans. I should like to take a great deal of land, and drain it, and\r\nmake a little colony, where everybody should work, and all the work\r\nshould be done well. I should know every one of the people and be their\r\nfriend. I am going to have great consultations with Mr. Garth: he can\r\ntell me almost everything I want to know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you _will_ be happy, if you have a plan, Dodo?\xe2\x80\x9d said Celia.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps little Arthur will like plans when he grows up, and then he\r\ncan help you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSir James was informed that same night that Dorothea was really quite\r\nset against marrying anybody at all, and was going to take to \xe2\x80\x9call\r\nsorts of plans,\xe2\x80\x9d just like what she used to have. Sir James made no\r\nremark. To his secret feeling there was something repulsive in a\r\nwoman\xe2\x80\x99s second marriage, and no match would prevent him from feeling it\r\na sort of desecration for Dorothea. He was aware that the world would\r\nregard such a sentiment as preposterous, especially in relation to a\r\nwoman of one-and-twenty; the practice of \xe2\x80\x9cthe world\xe2\x80\x9d being to treat of\r\na young widow\xe2\x80\x99s second marriage as certain and probably near, and to\r\nsmile with meaning if the widow acts accordingly. But if Dorothea did\r\nchoose to espouse her solitude, he felt that the resolution would well\r\nbecome her.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER LVI.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow happy is he born and taught\r\nThat serveth not another\xe2\x80\x99s will;\r\nWhose armor is his honest thought,\r\nAnd simple truth his only skill!\r\n. . . . . . .\r\nThis man is freed from servile bands\r\nOf hope to rise or fear to fall;\r\nLord of himself though not of lands;\r\nAnd having nothing yet hath all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x94SIR HENRY WOTTON.\r\n\r\n\r\nDorothea\xe2\x80\x99s confidence in Caleb Garth\xe2\x80\x99s knowledge, which had begun on\r\nher hearing that he approved of her cottages, had grown fast during her\r\nstay at Freshitt, Sir James having induced her to take rides over the\r\ntwo estates in company with himself and Caleb, who quite returned her\r\nadmiration, and told his wife that Mrs. Casaubon had a head for\r\nbusiness most uncommon in a woman. It must be remembered that by\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cbusiness\xe2\x80\x9d Caleb never meant money transactions, but the skilful\r\napplication of labor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMost uncommon!\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Caleb. \xe2\x80\x9cShe said a thing I often used to\r\nthink myself when I was a lad:\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98Mr. Garth, I should like to feel, if I\r\nlived to be old, that I had improved a great piece of land and built a\r\ngreat many good cottages, because the work is of a healthy kind while\r\nit is being done, and after it is done, men are the better for it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\nThose were the very words: she sees into things in that way.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut womanly, I hope,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Garth, half suspecting that Mrs.\r\nCasaubon might not hold the true principle of subordination.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, you can\xe2\x80\x99t think!\xe2\x80\x9d said Caleb, shaking his head. \xe2\x80\x9cYou would like to\r\nhear her speak, Susan. She speaks in such plain words, and a voice like\r\nmusic. Bless me! it reminds me of bits in the \xe2\x80\x98Messiah\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98and\r\nstraightway there appeared a multitude of the heavenly host, praising\r\nGod and saying;\xe2\x80\x99 it has a tone with it that satisfies your ear.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCaleb was very fond of music, and when he could afford it went to hear\r\nan oratorio that came within his reach, returning from it with a\r\nprofound reverence for this mighty structure of tones, which made him\r\nsit meditatively, looking on the floor and throwing much unutterable\r\nlanguage into his outstretched hands.\r\n\r\nWith this good understanding between them, it was natural that Dorothea\r\nasked Mr. Garth to undertake any business connected with the three\r\nfarms and the numerous tenements attached to Lowick Manor; indeed, his\r\nexpectation of getting work for two was being fast fulfilled. As he\r\nsaid, \xe2\x80\x9cBusiness breeds.\xe2\x80\x9d And one form of business which was beginning\r\nto breed just then was the construction of railways. A projected line\r\nwas to run through Lowick parish where the cattle had hitherto grazed\r\nin a peace unbroken by astonishment; and thus it happened that the\r\ninfant struggles of the railway system entered into the affairs of\r\nCaleb Garth, and determined the course of this history with regard to\r\ntwo persons who were dear to him. The submarine railway may have its\r\ndifficulties; but the bed of the sea is not divided among various\r\nlanded proprietors with claims for damages not only measurable but\r\nsentimental. In the hundred to which Middlemarch belonged railways were\r\nas exciting a topic as the Reform Bill or the imminent horrors of\r\nCholera, and those who held the most decided views on the subject were\r\nwomen and landholders. Women both old and young regarded travelling by\r\nsteam as presumptuous and dangerous, and argued against it by saying\r\nthat nothing should induce them to get into a railway carriage; while\r\nproprietors, differing from each other in their arguments as much as\r\nMr. Solomon Featherstone differed from Lord Medlicote, were yet\r\nunanimous in the opinion that in selling land, whether to the Enemy of\r\nmankind or to a company obliged to purchase, these pernicious agencies\r\nmust be made to pay a very high price to landowners for permission to\r\ninjure mankind.\r\n\r\nBut the slower wits, such as Mr. Solomon and Mrs. Waule, who both\r\noccupied land of their own, took a long time to arrive at this\r\nconclusion, their minds halting at the vivid conception of what it\r\nwould be to cut the Big Pasture in two, and turn it into three-cornered\r\nbits, which would be \xe2\x80\x9cnohow;\xe2\x80\x9d while accommodation-bridges and high\r\npayments were remote and incredible.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe cows will all cast their calves, brother,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Waule, in a\r\ntone of deep melancholy, \xe2\x80\x9cif the railway comes across the Near Close;\r\nand I shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t wonder at the mare too, if she was in foal. It\xe2\x80\x99s a poor\r\ntale if a widow\xe2\x80\x99s property is to be spaded away, and the law say\r\nnothing to it. What\xe2\x80\x99s to hinder \xe2\x80\x99em from cutting right and left if they\r\nbegin? It\xe2\x80\x99s well known, _I_ can\xe2\x80\x99t fight.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe best way would be to say nothing, and set somebody on to send \xe2\x80\x99em\r\naway with a flea in their ear, when they came spying and measuring,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid Solomon. \xe2\x80\x9cFolks did that about Brassing, by what I can understand.\r\nIt\xe2\x80\x99s all a pretence, if the truth was known, about their being forced\r\nto take one way. Let \xe2\x80\x99em go cutting in another parish. And I don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nbelieve in any pay to make amends for bringing a lot of ruffians to\r\ntrample your crops. Where\xe2\x80\x99s a company\xe2\x80\x99s pocket?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBrother Peter, God forgive him, got money out of a company,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs.\r\nWaule. \xe2\x80\x9cBut that was for the manganese. That wasn\xe2\x80\x99t for railways to\r\nblow you to pieces right and left.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, there\xe2\x80\x99s this to be said, Jane,\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Solomon concluded, lowering\r\nhis voice in a cautious manner\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cthe more spokes we put in their wheel,\r\nthe more they\xe2\x80\x99ll pay us to let \xe2\x80\x99em go on, if they must come whether or\r\nnot.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis reasoning of Mr. Solomon\xe2\x80\x99s was perhaps less thorough than he\r\nimagined, his cunning bearing about the same relation to the course of\r\nrailways as the cunning of a diplomatist bears to the general chill or\r\ncatarrh of the solar system. But he set about acting on his views in a\r\nthoroughly diplomatic manner, by stimulating suspicion. His side of\r\nLowick was the most remote from the village, and the houses of the\r\nlaboring people were either lone cottages or were collected in a hamlet\r\ncalled Frick, where a water-mill and some stone-pits made a little\r\ncentre of slow, heavy-shouldered industry.\r\n\r\nIn the absence of any precise idea as to what railways were, public\r\nopinion in Frick was against them; for the human mind in that grassy\r\ncorner had not the proverbial tendency to admire the unknown, holding\r\nrather that it was likely to be against the poor man, and that\r\nsuspicion was the only wise attitude with regard to it. Even the rumor\r\nof Reform had not yet excited any millennial expectations in Frick,\r\nthere being no definite promise in it, as of gratuitous grains to\r\nfatten Hiram Ford\xe2\x80\x99s pig, or of a publican at the \xe2\x80\x9cWeights and Scales\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nwho would brew beer for nothing, or of an offer on the part of the\r\nthree neighboring farmers to raise wages during winter. And without\r\ndistinct good of this kind in its promises, Reform seemed on a footing\r\nwith the bragging of pedlers, which was a hint for distrust to every\r\nknowing person. The men of Frick were not ill-fed, and were less given\r\nto fanaticism than to a strong muscular suspicion; less inclined to\r\nbelieve that they were peculiarly cared for by heaven, than to regard\r\nheaven itself as rather disposed to take them in\xe2\x80\x94a disposition\r\nobservable in the weather.\r\n\r\nThus the mind of Frick was exactly of the sort for Mr. Solomon\r\nFeatherstone to work upon, he having more plenteous ideas of the same\r\norder, with a suspicion of heaven and earth which was better fed and\r\nmore entirely at leisure. Solomon was overseer of the roads at that\r\ntime, and on his slow-paced cob often took his rounds by Frick to look\r\nat the workmen getting the stones there, pausing with a mysterious\r\ndeliberation, which might have misled you into supposing that he had\r\nsome other reason for staying than the mere want of impulse to move.\r\nAfter looking for a long while at any work that was going on, he would\r\nraise his eyes a little and look at the horizon; finally he would shake\r\nhis bridle, touch his horse with the whip, and get it to move slowly\r\nonward. The hour-hand of a clock was quick by comparison with Mr.\r\nSolomon, who had an agreeable sense that he could afford to be slow. He\r\nwas in the habit of pausing for a cautious, vaguely designing chat with\r\nevery hedger or ditcher on his way, and was especially willing to\r\nlisten even to news which he had heard before, feeling himself at an\r\nadvantage over all narrators in partially disbelieving them. One day,\r\nhowever, he got into a dialogue with Hiram Ford, a wagoner, in which he\r\nhimself contributed information. He wished to know whether Hiram had\r\nseen fellows with staves and instruments spying about: they called\r\nthemselves railroad people, but there was no telling what they were or\r\nwhat they meant to do. The least they pretended was that they were\r\ngoing to cut Lowick Parish into sixes and sevens.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, there\xe2\x80\x99ll be no stirrin\xe2\x80\x99 from one pla-ace to another,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hiram,\r\nthinking of his wagon and horses.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot a bit,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Solomon. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd cutting up fine land such as this\r\nparish! Let \xe2\x80\x99em go into Tipton, say I. But there\xe2\x80\x99s no knowing what\r\nthere is at the bottom of it. Traffic is what they put for\xe2\x80\x99ard; but\r\nit\xe2\x80\x99s to do harm to the land and the poor man in the long-run.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, they\xe2\x80\x99re Lunnon chaps, I reckon,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hiram, who had a dim notion\r\nof London as a centre of hostility to the country.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, to be sure. And in some parts against Brassing, by what I\xe2\x80\x99ve heard\r\nsay, the folks fell on \xe2\x80\x99em when they were spying, and broke their\r\npeep-holes as they carry, and drove \xe2\x80\x99em away, so as they knew better\r\nthan come again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt war good foon, I\xe2\x80\x99d be bound,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hiram, whose fun was much\r\nrestricted by circumstances.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t meddle with \xe2\x80\x99em myself,\xe2\x80\x9d said Solomon. \xe2\x80\x9cBut some say\r\nthis country\xe2\x80\x99s seen its best days, and the sign is, as it\xe2\x80\x99s being\r\noverrun with these fellows trampling right and left, and wanting to cut\r\nit up into railways; and all for the big traffic to swallow up the\r\nlittle, so as there shan\xe2\x80\x99t be a team left on the land, nor a whip to\r\ncrack.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll crack _my_ whip about their ear\xe2\x80\x99n, afore they bring it to that,\r\nthough,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hiram, while Mr. Solomon, shaking his bridle, moved\r\nonward.\r\n\r\nNettle-seed needs no digging. The ruin of this countryside by railroads\r\nwas discussed, not only at the \xe2\x80\x9cWeights and Scales,\xe2\x80\x9d but in the\r\nhay-field, where the muster of working hands gave opportunities for\r\ntalk such as were rarely had through the rural year.\r\n\r\nOne morning, not long after that interview between Mr. Farebrother and\r\nMary Garth, in which she confessed to him her feeling for Fred Vincy,\r\nit happened that her father had some business which took him to\r\nYoddrell\xe2\x80\x99s farm in the direction of Frick: it was to measure and value\r\nan outlying piece of land belonging to Lowick Manor, which Caleb\r\nexpected to dispose of advantageously for Dorothea (it must be\r\nconfessed that his bias was towards getting the best possible terms\r\nfrom railroad companies). He put up his gig at Yoddrell\xe2\x80\x99s, and in\r\nwalking with his assistant and measuring-chain to the scene of his\r\nwork, he encountered the party of the company\xe2\x80\x99s agents, who were\r\nadjusting their spirit-level. After a little chat he left them,\r\nobserving that by-and-by they would reach him again where he was going\r\nto measure. It was one of those gray mornings after light rains, which\r\nbecome delicious about twelve o\xe2\x80\x99clock, when the clouds part a little,\r\nand the scent of the earth is sweet along the lanes and by the\r\nhedgerows.\r\n\r\nThe scent would have been sweeter to Fred Vincy, who was coming along\r\nthe lanes on horseback, if his mind had not been worried by\r\nunsuccessful efforts to imagine what he was to do, with his father on\r\none side expecting him straightway to enter the Church, with Mary on\r\nthe other threatening to forsake him if he did enter it, and with the\r\nworking-day world showing no eager need whatever of a young gentleman\r\nwithout capital and generally unskilled. It was the harder to Fred\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndisposition because his father, satisfied that he was no longer\r\nrebellious, was in good humor with him, and had sent him on this\r\npleasant ride to see after some greyhounds. Even when he had fixed on\r\nwhat he should do, there would be the task of telling his father. But\r\nit must be admitted that the fixing, which had to come first, was the\r\nmore difficult task:\xe2\x80\x94what secular avocation on earth was there for a\r\nyoung man (whose friends could not get him an \xe2\x80\x9cappointment\xe2\x80\x9d) which was\r\nat once gentlemanly, lucrative, and to be followed without special\r\nknowledge? Riding along the lanes by Frick in this mood, and slackening\r\nhis pace while he reflected whether he should venture to go round by\r\nLowick Parsonage to call on Mary, he could see over the hedges from one\r\nfield to another. Suddenly a noise roused his attention, and on the far\r\nside of a field on his left hand he could see six or seven men in\r\nsmock-frocks with hay-forks in their hands making an offensive approach\r\ntowards the four railway agents who were facing them, while Caleb Garth\r\nand his assistant were hastening across the field to join the\r\nthreatened group. Fred, delayed a few moments by having to find the\r\ngate, could not gallop up to the spot before the party in smock-frocks,\r\nwhose work of turning the hay had not been too pressing after\r\nswallowing their mid-day beer, were driving the men in coats before\r\nthem with their hay-forks; while Caleb Garth\xe2\x80\x99s assistant, a lad of\r\nseventeen, who had snatched up the spirit-level at Caleb\xe2\x80\x99s order, had\r\nbeen knocked down and seemed to be lying helpless. The coated men had\r\nthe advantage as runners, and Fred covered their retreat by getting in\r\nfront of the smock-frocks and charging them suddenly enough to throw\r\ntheir chase into confusion. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you confounded fools mean?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nshouted Fred, pursuing the divided group in a zigzag, and cutting right\r\nand left with his whip. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll swear to every one of you before the\r\nmagistrate. You\xe2\x80\x99ve knocked the lad down and killed him, for what I\r\nknow. You\xe2\x80\x99ll every one of you be hanged at the next assizes, if you\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t mind,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fred, who afterwards laughed heartily as he\r\nremembered his own phrases.\r\n\r\nThe laborers had been driven through the gate-way into their hay-field,\r\nand Fred had checked his horse, when Hiram Ford, observing himself at a\r\nsafe challenging distance, turned back and shouted a defiance which he\r\ndid not know to be Homeric.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYo\xe2\x80\x99re a coward, yo are. Yo git off your horse, young measter, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\nhave a round wi\xe2\x80\x99 ye, I wull. Yo daredn\xe2\x80\x99t come on wi\xe2\x80\x99out your hoss an\xe2\x80\x99\r\nwhip. I\xe2\x80\x99d soon knock the breath out on ye, I would.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWait a minute, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll come back presently, and have a round with you\r\nall in turn, if you like,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fred, who felt confidence in his power\r\nof boxing with his dearly beloved brethren. But just now he wanted to\r\nhasten back to Caleb and the prostrate youth.\r\n\r\nThe lad\xe2\x80\x99s ankle was strained, and he was in much pain from it, but he\r\nwas no further hurt, and Fred placed him on the horse that he might\r\nride to Yoddrell\xe2\x80\x99s and be taken care of there.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet them put the horse in the stable, and tell the surveyors they can\r\ncome back for their traps,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fred. \xe2\x80\x9cThe ground is clear now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caleb, \xe2\x80\x9chere\xe2\x80\x99s a breakage. They\xe2\x80\x99ll have to give up for\r\nto-day, and it will be as well. Here, take the things before you on the\r\nhorse, Tom. They\xe2\x80\x99ll see you coming, and they\xe2\x80\x99ll turn back.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m glad I happened to be here at the right moment, Mr. Garth,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nFred, as Tom rode away. \xe2\x80\x9cNo knowing what might have happened if the\r\ncavalry had not come up in time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, ay, it was lucky,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caleb, speaking rather absently, and\r\nlooking towards the spot where he had been at work at the moment of\r\ninterruption. \xe2\x80\x9cBut\xe2\x80\x94deuce take it\xe2\x80\x94this is what comes of men being\r\nfools\xe2\x80\x94I\xe2\x80\x99m hindered of my day\xe2\x80\x99s work. I can\xe2\x80\x99t get along without somebody\r\nto help me with the measuring-chain. However!\xe2\x80\x9d He was beginning to move\r\ntowards the spot with a look of vexation, as if he had forgotten Fred\xe2\x80\x99s\r\npresence, but suddenly he turned round and said quickly, \xe2\x80\x9cWhat have you\r\ngot to do to-day, young fellow?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing, Mr. Garth. I\xe2\x80\x99ll help you with pleasure\xe2\x80\x94can I?\xe2\x80\x9d said Fred,\r\nwith a sense that he should be courting Mary when he was helping her\r\nfather.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you mustn\xe2\x80\x99t mind stooping and getting hot.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t mind anything. Only I want to go first and have a round with\r\nthat hulky fellow who turned to challenge me. It would be a good lesson\r\nfor him. I shall not be five minutes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNonsense!\xe2\x80\x9d said Caleb, with his most peremptory intonation. \xe2\x80\x9cI shall\r\ngo and speak to the men myself. It\xe2\x80\x99s all ignorance. Somebody has been\r\ntelling them lies. The poor fools don\xe2\x80\x99t know any better.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shall go with you, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fred.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no; stay where you are. I don\xe2\x80\x99t want your young blood. I can take\r\ncare of myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCaleb was a powerful man and knew little of any fear except the fear of\r\nhurting others and the fear of having to speechify. But he felt it his\r\nduty at this moment to try and give a little harangue. There was a\r\nstriking mixture in him\xe2\x80\x94which came from his having always been a\r\nhard-working man himself\xe2\x80\x94of rigorous notions about workmen and\r\npractical indulgence towards them. To do a good day\xe2\x80\x99s work and to do it\r\nwell, he held to be part of their welfare, as it was the chief part of\r\nhis own happiness; but he had a strong sense of fellowship with them.\r\nWhen he advanced towards the laborers they had not gone to work again,\r\nbut were standing in that form of rural grouping which consists in each\r\nturning a shoulder towards the other, at a distance of two or three\r\nyards. They looked rather sulkily at Caleb, who walked quickly with one\r\nhand in his pocket and the other thrust between the buttons of his\r\nwaistcoat, and had his every-day mild air when he paused among them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, my lads, how\xe2\x80\x99s this?\xe2\x80\x9d he began, taking as usual to brief phrases,\r\nwhich seemed pregnant to himself, because he had many thoughts lying\r\nunder them, like the abundant roots of a plant that just manages to\r\npeep above the water. \xe2\x80\x9cHow came you to make such a mistake as this?\r\nSomebody has been telling you lies. You thought those men up there\r\nwanted to do mischief.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAw!\xe2\x80\x9d was the answer, dropped at intervals by each according to his\r\ndegree of unreadiness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNonsense! No such thing! They\xe2\x80\x99re looking out to see which way the\r\nrailroad is to take. Now, my lads, you can\xe2\x80\x99t hinder the railroad: it\r\nwill be made whether you like it or not. And if you go fighting against\r\nit, you\xe2\x80\x99ll get yourselves into trouble. The law gives those men leave\r\nto come here on the land. The owner has nothing to say against it, and\r\nif you meddle with them you\xe2\x80\x99ll have to do with the constable and\r\nJustice Blakesley, and with the handcuffs and Middlemarch jail. And you\r\nmight be in for it now, if anybody informed against you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCaleb paused here, and perhaps the greatest orator could not have\r\nchosen either his pause or his images better for the occasion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut come, you didn\xe2\x80\x99t mean any harm. Somebody told you the railroad was\r\na bad thing. That was a lie. It may do a bit of harm here and there, to\r\nthis and to that; and so does the sun in heaven. But the railway\xe2\x80\x99s a\r\ngood thing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAw! good for the big folks to make money out on,\xe2\x80\x9d said old Timothy\r\nCooper, who had stayed behind turning his hay while the others had been\r\ngone on their spree;\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99n seen lots o\xe2\x80\x99 things turn up sin\xe2\x80\x99 I war a\r\nyoung un\xe2\x80\x94the war an\xe2\x80\x99 the peace, and the canells, an\xe2\x80\x99 the oald King\r\nGeorge, an\xe2\x80\x99 the Regen\xe2\x80\x99, an\xe2\x80\x99 the new King George, an\xe2\x80\x99 the new un as has\r\ngot a new ne-ame\xe2\x80\x94an\xe2\x80\x99 it\xe2\x80\x99s been all aloike to the poor mon. What\xe2\x80\x99s the\r\ncanells been t\xe2\x80\x99 him? They\xe2\x80\x99n brought him neyther me-at nor be-acon, nor\r\nwage to lay by, if he didn\xe2\x80\x99t save it wi\xe2\x80\x99 clemmin\xe2\x80\x99 his own inside. Times\r\nha\xe2\x80\x99 got wusser for him sin\xe2\x80\x99 I war a young un. An\xe2\x80\x99 so it\xe2\x80\x99ll be wi\xe2\x80\x99 the\r\nrailroads. They\xe2\x80\x99ll on\xe2\x80\x99y leave the poor mon furder behind. But them are\r\nfools as meddle, and so I told the chaps here. This is the big folks\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nworld, this is. But yo\xe2\x80\x99re for the big folks, Muster Garth, yo are.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTimothy was a wiry old laborer, of a type lingering in those times\xe2\x80\x94who\r\nhad his savings in a stocking-foot, lived in a lone cottage, and was\r\nnot to be wrought on by any oratory, having as little of the feudal\r\nspirit, and believing as little, as if he had not been totally\r\nunacquainted with the Age of Reason and the Rights of Man. Caleb was in\r\na difficulty known to any person attempting in dark times and\r\nunassisted by miracle to reason with rustics who are in possession of\r\nan undeniable truth which they know through a hard process of feeling,\r\nand can let it fall like a giant\xe2\x80\x99s club on your neatly carved argument\r\nfor a social benefit which they do not feel. Caleb had no cant at\r\ncommand, even if he could have chosen to use it; and he had been\r\naccustomed to meet all such difficulties in no other way than by doing\r\nhis \xe2\x80\x9cbusiness\xe2\x80\x9d faithfully. He answered\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you don\xe2\x80\x99t think well of me, Tim, never mind; that\xe2\x80\x99s neither here\r\nnor there now. Things may be bad for the poor man\xe2\x80\x94bad they are; but I\r\nwant the lads here not to do what will make things worse for\r\nthemselves. The cattle may have a heavy load, but it won\xe2\x80\x99t help \xe2\x80\x99em to\r\nthrow it over into the roadside pit, when it\xe2\x80\x99s partly their own\r\nfodder.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe war on\xe2\x80\x99y for a bit o\xe2\x80\x99 foon,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hiram, who was beginning to see\r\nconsequences. \xe2\x80\x9cThat war all we war arter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, promise me not to meddle again, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll see that nobody informs\r\nagainst you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99n ne\xe2\x80\x99er meddled, an\xe2\x80\x99 I\xe2\x80\x99n no call to promise,\xe2\x80\x9d said Timothy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, but the rest. Come, I\xe2\x80\x99m as hard at work as any of you to-day, and\r\nI can\xe2\x80\x99t spare much time. Say you\xe2\x80\x99ll be quiet without the constable.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAw, we wooant meddle\xe2\x80\x94they may do as they loike for oos\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94were the forms\r\nin which Caleb got his pledges; and then he hastened back to Fred, who\r\nhad followed him, and watched him in the gateway.\r\n\r\nThey went to work, and Fred helped vigorously. His spirits had risen,\r\nand he heartily enjoyed a good slip in the moist earth under the\r\nhedgerow, which soiled his perfect summer trousers. Was it his\r\nsuccessful onset which had elated him, or the satisfaction of helping\r\nMary\xe2\x80\x99s father? Something more. The accidents of the morning had helped\r\nhis frustrated imagination to shape an employment for himself which had\r\nseveral attractions. I am not sure that certain fibres in Mr. Garth\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nmind had not resumed their old vibration towards the very end which now\r\nrevealed itself to Fred. For the effective accident is but the touch of\r\nfire where there is oil and tow; and it always appeared to Fred that\r\nthe railway brought the needed touch. But they went on in silence\r\nexcept when their business demanded speech. At last, when they had\r\nfinished and were walking away, Mr. Garth said\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA young fellow needn\xe2\x80\x99t be a B. A. to do this sort of work, eh, Fred?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wish I had taken to it before I had thought of being a B. A.,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nFred. He paused a moment, and then added, more hesitatingly, \xe2\x80\x9cDo you\r\nthink I am too old to learn your business, Mr. Garth?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy business is of many sorts, my boy,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Garth, smiling. \xe2\x80\x9cA\r\ngood deal of what I know can only come from experience: you can\xe2\x80\x99t learn\r\nit off as you learn things out of a book. But you are young enough to\r\nlay a foundation yet.\xe2\x80\x9d Caleb pronounced the last sentence emphatically,\r\nbut paused in some uncertainty. He had been under the impression lately\r\nthat Fred had made up his mind to enter the Church.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou do think I could do some good at it, if I were to try?\xe2\x80\x9d said Fred,\r\nmore eagerly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat depends,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caleb, turning his head on one side and lowering\r\nhis voice, with the air of a man who felt himself to be saying\r\nsomething deeply religious. \xe2\x80\x9cYou must be sure of two things: you must\r\nlove your work, and not be always looking over the edge of it, wanting\r\nyour play to begin. And the other is, you must not be ashamed of your\r\nwork, and think it would be more honorable to you to be doing something\r\nelse. You must have a pride in your own work and in learning to do it\r\nwell, and not be always saying, There\xe2\x80\x99s this and there\xe2\x80\x99s that\xe2\x80\x94if I had\r\nthis or that to do, I might make something of it. No matter what a man\r\nis\xe2\x80\x94I wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t give twopence for him\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94here Caleb\xe2\x80\x99s mouth looked bitter,\r\nand he snapped his fingers\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cwhether he was the prime minister or the\r\nrick-thatcher, if he didn\xe2\x80\x99t do well what he undertook to do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can never feel that I should do that in being a clergyman,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nFred, meaning to take a step in argument.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen let it alone, my boy,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caleb, abruptly, \xe2\x80\x9celse you\xe2\x80\x99ll never\r\nbe easy. Or, if you _are_ easy, you\xe2\x80\x99ll be a poor stick.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is very nearly what Mary thinks about it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fred, coloring.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think you must know what I feel for Mary, Mr. Garth: I hope it does\r\nnot displease you that I have always loved her better than any one\r\nelse, and that I shall never love any one as I love her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe expression of Caleb\xe2\x80\x99s face was visibly softening while Fred spoke.\r\nBut he swung his head with a solemn slowness, and said\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat makes things more serious, Fred, if you want to take Mary\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhappiness into your keeping.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know that, Mr. Garth,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fred, eagerly, \xe2\x80\x9cand I would do anything\r\nfor _her_. She says she will never have me if I go into the Church; and\r\nI shall be the most miserable devil in the world if I lose all hope of\r\nMary. Really, if I could get some other profession, business\xe2\x80\x94anything\r\nthat I am at all fit for, I would work hard, I would deserve your good\r\nopinion. I should like to have to do with outdoor things. I know a good\r\ndeal about land and cattle already. I used to believe, you know\xe2\x80\x94though\r\nyou will think me rather foolish for it\xe2\x80\x94that I should have land of my\r\nown. I am sure knowledge of that sort would come easily to me,\r\nespecially if I could be under you in any way.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSoftly, my boy,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caleb, having the image of \xe2\x80\x9cSusan\xe2\x80\x9d before his\r\neyes. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat have you said to your father about all this?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing, yet; but I must tell him. I am only waiting to know what I\r\ncan do instead of entering the Church. I am very sorry to disappoint\r\nhim, but a man ought to be allowed to judge for himself when he is\r\nfour-and-twenty. How could I know when I was fifteen, what it would be\r\nright for me to do now? My education was a mistake.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut hearken to this, Fred,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caleb. \xe2\x80\x9cAre you sure Mary is fond of\r\nyou, or would ever have you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI asked Mr. Farebrother to talk to her, because she had forbidden me\xe2\x80\x94I\r\ndidn\xe2\x80\x99t know what else to do,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fred, apologetically. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd he says\r\nthat I have every reason to hope, if I can put myself in an honorable\r\nposition\xe2\x80\x94I mean, out of the Church. I dare say you think it\r\nunwarrantable in me, Mr. Garth, to be troubling you and obtruding my\r\nown wishes about Mary, before I have done anything at all for myself.\r\nOf course I have not the least claim\xe2\x80\x94indeed, I have already a debt to\r\nyou which will never be discharged, even when I have been able to pay\r\nit in the shape of money.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, my boy, you have a claim,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caleb, with much feeling in his\r\nvoice. \xe2\x80\x9cThe young ones have always a claim on the old to help them\r\nforward. I was young myself once and had to do without much help; but\r\nhelp would have been welcome to me, if it had been only for the\r\nfellow-feeling\xe2\x80\x99s sake. But I must consider. Come to me to-morrow at the\r\noffice, at nine o\xe2\x80\x99clock. At the office, mind.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Garth would take no important step without consulting Susan, but it\r\nmust be confessed that before he reached home he had taken his\r\nresolution. With regard to a large number of matters about which other\r\nmen are decided or obstinate, he was the most easily manageable man in\r\nthe world. He never knew what meat he would choose, and if Susan had\r\nsaid that they ought to live in a four-roomed cottage, in order to\r\nsave, he would have said, \xe2\x80\x9cLet us go,\xe2\x80\x9d without inquiring into details.\r\nBut where Caleb\xe2\x80\x99s feeling and judgment strongly pronounced, he was a\r\nruler; and in spite of his mildness and timidity in reproving, every\r\none about him knew that on the exceptional occasions when he chose, he\r\nwas absolute. He never, indeed, chose to be absolute except on some one\r\nelse\xe2\x80\x99s behalf. On ninety-nine points Mrs. Garth decided, but on the\r\nhundredth she was often aware that she would have to perform the\r\nsingularly difficult task of carrying out her own principle, and to\r\nmake herself subordinate.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is come round as I thought, Susan,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caleb, when they were\r\nseated alone in the evening. He had already narrated the adventure\r\nwhich had brought about Fred\xe2\x80\x99s sharing in his work, but had kept back\r\nthe further result. \xe2\x80\x9cThe children _are_ fond of each other\xe2\x80\x94I mean, Fred\r\nand Mary.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Garth laid her work on her knee, and fixed her penetrating eyes\r\nanxiously on her husband.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAfter we\xe2\x80\x99d done our work, Fred poured it all out to me. He can\xe2\x80\x99t bear\r\nto be a clergyman, and Mary says she won\xe2\x80\x99t have him if he is one; and\r\nthe lad would like to be under me and give his mind to business. And\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ve determined to take him and make a man of him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCaleb!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Garth, in a deep contralto, expressive of resigned\r\nastonishment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a fine thing to do,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Garth, settling himself firmly\r\nagainst the back of his chair, and grasping the elbows. \xe2\x80\x9cI shall have\r\ntrouble with him, but I think I shall carry it through. The lad loves\r\nMary, and a true love for a good woman is a great thing, Susan. It\r\nshapes many a rough fellow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHas Mary spoken to you on the subject?\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs Garth, secretly a\r\nlittle hurt that she had to be informed on it herself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot a word. I asked her about Fred once; I gave her a bit of a\r\nwarning. But she assured me she would never marry an idle\r\nself-indulgent man\xe2\x80\x94nothing since. But it seems Fred set on Mr.\r\nFarebrother to talk to her, because she had forbidden him to speak\r\nhimself, and Mr. Farebrother has found out that she is fond of Fred,\r\nbut says he must not be a clergyman. Fred\xe2\x80\x99s heart is fixed on Mary,\r\nthat I can see: it gives me a good opinion of the lad\xe2\x80\x94and we always\r\nliked him, Susan.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is a pity for Mary, I think,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Garth.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy\xe2\x80\x94a pity?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause, Caleb, she might have had a man who is worth twenty Fred\r\nVincy\xe2\x80\x99s.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh?\xe2\x80\x9d said Caleb, with surprise.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI firmly believe that Mr. Farebrother is attached to her, and meant to\r\nmake her an offer; but of course, now that Fred has used him as an\r\nenvoy, there is an end to that better prospect.\xe2\x80\x9d There was a severe\r\nprecision in Mrs. Garth\xe2\x80\x99s utterance. She was vexed and disappointed,\r\nbut she was bent on abstaining from useless words.\r\n\r\nCaleb was silent a few moments under a conflict of feelings. He looked\r\nat the floor and moved his head and hands in accompaniment to some\r\ninward argumentation. At last he said\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat would have made me very proud and happy, Susan, and I should have\r\nbeen glad for your sake. I\xe2\x80\x99ve always felt that your belongings have\r\nnever been on a level with you. But you took me, though I was a plain\r\nman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI took the best and cleverest man I had ever known,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Garth,\r\nconvinced that _she_ would never have loved any one who came short of\r\nthat mark.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, perhaps others thought you might have done better. But it would\r\nhave been worse for me. And that is what touches me close about Fred.\r\nThe lad is good at bottom, and clever enough to do, if he\xe2\x80\x99s put in the\r\nright way; and he loves and honors my daughter beyond anything, and she\r\nhas given him a sort of promise according to what he turns out. I say,\r\nthat young man\xe2\x80\x99s soul is in my hand; and I\xe2\x80\x99ll do the best I can for\r\nhim, so help me God! It\xe2\x80\x99s my duty, Susan.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Garth was not given to tears, but there was a large one rolling\r\ndown her face before her husband had finished. It came from the\r\npressure of various feelings, in which there was much affection and\r\nsome vexation. She wiped it away quickly, saying\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFew men besides you would think it a duty to add to their anxieties in\r\nthat way, Caleb.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat signifies nothing\xe2\x80\x94what other men would think. I\xe2\x80\x99ve got a clear\r\nfeeling inside me, and that I shall follow; and I hope your heart will\r\ngo with me, Susan, in making everything as light as can be to Mary,\r\npoor child.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCaleb, leaning back in his chair, looked with anxious appeal towards\r\nhis wife. She rose and kissed him, saying, \xe2\x80\x9cGod bless you, Caleb! Our\r\nchildren have a good father.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut she went out and had a hearty cry to make up for the suppression of\r\nher words. She felt sure that her husband\xe2\x80\x99s conduct would be\r\nmisunderstood, and about Fred she was rational and unhopeful. Which\r\nwould turn out to have the more foresight in it\xe2\x80\x94her rationality or\r\nCaleb\xe2\x80\x99s ardent generosity?\r\n\r\nWhen Fred went to the office the next morning, there was a test to be\r\ngone through which he was not prepared for.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow Fred,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caleb, \xe2\x80\x9cyou will have some desk-work. I have always\r\ndone a good deal of writing myself, but I can\xe2\x80\x99t do without help, and as\r\nI want you to understand the accounts and get the values into your\r\nhead, I mean to do without another clerk. So you must buckle to. How\r\nare you at writing and arithmetic?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFred felt an awkward movement of the heart; he had not thought of\r\ndesk-work; but he was in a resolute mood, and not going to shrink. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m\r\nnot afraid of arithmetic, Mr. Garth: it always came easily to me. I\r\nthink you know my writing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us see,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caleb, taking up a pen, examining it carefully and\r\nhanding it, well dipped, to Fred with a sheet of ruled paper. \xe2\x80\x9cCopy me\r\na line or two of that valuation, with the figures at the end.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt that time the opinion existed that it was beneath a gentleman to\r\nwrite legibly, or with a hand in the least suitable to a clerk. Fred\r\nwrote the lines demanded in a hand as gentlemanly as that of any\r\nviscount or bishop of the day: the vowels were all alike and the\r\nconsonants only distinguishable as turning up or down, the strokes had\r\na blotted solidity and the letters disdained to keep the line\xe2\x80\x94in short,\r\nit was a manuscript of that venerable kind easy to interpret when you\r\nknow beforehand what the writer means.\r\n\r\nAs Caleb looked on, his visage showed a growing depression, but when\r\nFred handed him the paper he gave something like a snarl, and rapped\r\nthe paper passionately with the back of his hand. Bad work like this\r\ndispelled all Caleb\xe2\x80\x99s mildness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe deuce!\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed, snarlingly. \xe2\x80\x9cTo think that this is a country\r\nwhere a man\xe2\x80\x99s education may cost hundreds and hundreds, and it turns\r\nyou out this!\xe2\x80\x9d Then in a more pathetic tone, pushing up his spectacles\r\nand looking at the unfortunate scribe, \xe2\x80\x9cThe Lord have mercy on us,\r\nFred, I can\xe2\x80\x99t put up with this!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat can I do, Mr. Garth?\xe2\x80\x9d said Fred, whose spirits had sunk very low,\r\nnot only at the estimate of his handwriting, but at the vision of\r\nhimself as liable to be ranked with office clerks.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo? Why, you must learn to form your letters and keep the line. What\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nthe use of writing at all if nobody can understand it?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Caleb,\r\nenergetically, quite preoccupied with the bad quality of the work. \xe2\x80\x9cIs\r\nthere so little business in the world that you must be sending puzzles\r\nover the country? But that\xe2\x80\x99s the way people are brought up. I should\r\nlose no end of time with the letters some people send me, if Susan did\r\nnot make them out for me. It\xe2\x80\x99s disgusting.\xe2\x80\x9d Here Caleb tossed the paper\r\nfrom him.\r\n\r\nAny stranger peeping into the office at that moment might have wondered\r\nwhat was the drama between the indignant man of business, and the\r\nfine-looking young fellow whose blond complexion was getting rather\r\npatchy as he bit his lip with mortification. Fred was struggling with\r\nmany thoughts. Mr. Garth had been so kind and encouraging at the\r\nbeginning of their interview, that gratitude and hopefulness had been\r\nat a high pitch, and the downfall was proportionate. He had not thought\r\nof desk-work\xe2\x80\x94in fact, like the majority of young gentlemen, he wanted\r\nan occupation which should be free from disagreeables. I cannot tell\r\nwhat might have been the consequences if he had not distinctly promised\r\nhimself that he would go to Lowick to see Mary and tell her that he was\r\nengaged to work under her father. He did not like to disappoint himself\r\nthere.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am very sorry,\xe2\x80\x9d were all the words that he could muster. But Mr.\r\nGarth was already relenting.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe must make the best of it, Fred,\xe2\x80\x9d he began, with a return to his\r\nusual quiet tone. \xe2\x80\x9cEvery man can learn to write. I taught myself. Go at\r\nit with a will, and sit up at night if the day-time isn\xe2\x80\x99t enough. We\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\nbe patient, my boy. Callum shall go on with the books for a bit, while\r\nyou are learning. But now I must be off,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caleb, rising. \xe2\x80\x9cYou must\r\nlet your father know our agreement. You\xe2\x80\x99ll save me Callum\xe2\x80\x99s salary, you\r\nknow, when you can write; and I can afford to give you eighty pounds\r\nfor the first year, and more after.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhen Fred made the necessary disclosure to his parents, the relative\r\neffect on the two was a surprise which entered very deeply into his\r\nmemory. He went straight from Mr. Garth\xe2\x80\x99s office to the warehouse,\r\nrightly feeling that the most respectful way in which he could behave\r\nto his father was to make the painful communication as gravely and\r\nformally as possible. Moreover, the decision would be more certainly\r\nunderstood to be final, if the interview took place in his father\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ngravest hours, which were always those spent in his private room at the\r\nwarehouse.\r\n\r\nFred entered on the subject directly, and declared briefly what he had\r\ndone and was resolved to do, expressing at the end his regret that he\r\nshould be the cause of disappointment to his father, and taking the\r\nblame on his own deficiencies. The regret was genuine, and inspired\r\nFred with strong, simple words.\r\n\r\nMr. Vincy listened in profound surprise without uttering even an\r\nexclamation, a silence which in his impatient temperament was a sign of\r\nunusual emotion. He had not been in good spirits about trade that\r\nmorning, and the slight bitterness in his lips grew intense as he\r\nlistened. When Fred had ended, there was a pause of nearly a minute,\r\nduring which Mr. Vincy replaced a book in his desk and turned the key\r\nemphatically. Then he looked at his son steadily, and said\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo you\xe2\x80\x99ve made up your mind at last, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, father.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery well; stick to it. I\xe2\x80\x99ve no more to say. You\xe2\x80\x99ve thrown away your\r\neducation, and gone down a step in life, when I had given you the means\r\nof rising, that\xe2\x80\x99s all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am very sorry that we differ, father. I think I can be quite as much\r\nof a gentleman at the work I have undertaken, as if I had been a\r\ncurate. But I am grateful to you for wishing to do the best for me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery well; I have no more to say. I wash my hands of you. I only hope,\r\nwhen you have a son of your own he will make a better return for the\r\npains you spend on him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis was very cutting to Fred. His father was using that unfair\r\nadvantage possessed by us all when we are in a pathetic situation and\r\nsee our own past as if it were simply part of the pathos. In reality,\r\nMr. Vincy\xe2\x80\x99s wishes about his son had had a great deal of pride,\r\ninconsiderateness, and egoistic folly in them. But still the\r\ndisappointed father held a strong lever; and Fred felt as if he were\r\nbeing banished with a malediction.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hope you will not object to my remaining at home, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d he said,\r\nafter rising to go; \xe2\x80\x9cI shall have a sufficient salary to pay for my\r\nboard, as of course I should wish to do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBoard be hanged!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Vincy, recovering himself in his disgust at\r\nthe notion that Fred\xe2\x80\x99s keep would be missed at his table. \xe2\x80\x9cOf course\r\nyour mother will want you to stay. But I shall keep no horse for you,\r\nyou understand; and you will pay your own tailor. You will do with a\r\nsuit or two less, I fancy, when you have to pay for \xe2\x80\x99em.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFred lingered; there was still something to be said. At last it came.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hope you will shake hands with me, father, and forgive me the\r\nvexation I have caused you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Vincy from his chair threw a quick glance upward at his son, who\r\nhad advanced near to him, and then gave his hand, saying hurriedly,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes, let us say no more.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFred went through much more narrative and explanation with his mother,\r\nbut she was inconsolable, having before her eyes what perhaps her\r\nhusband had never thought of, the certainty that Fred would marry Mary\r\nGarth, that her life would henceforth be spoiled by a perpetual\r\ninfusion of Garths and their ways, and that her darling boy, with his\r\nbeautiful face and stylish air \xe2\x80\x9cbeyond anybody else\xe2\x80\x99s son in\r\nMiddlemarch,\xe2\x80\x9d would be sure to get like that family in plainness of\r\nappearance and carelessness about his clothes. To her it seemed that\r\nthere was a Garth conspiracy to get possession of the desirable Fred,\r\nbut she dared not enlarge on this opinion, because a slight hint of it\r\nhad made him \xe2\x80\x9cfly out\xe2\x80\x9d at her as he had never done before. Her temper\r\nwas too sweet for her to show any anger, but she felt that her\r\nhappiness had received a bruise, and for several days merely to look at\r\nFred made her cry a little as if he were the subject of some baleful\r\nprophecy. Perhaps she was the slower to recover her usual cheerfulness\r\nbecause Fred had warned her that she must not reopen the sore question\r\nwith his father, who had accepted his decision and forgiven him. If her\r\nhusband had been vehement against Fred, she would have been urged into\r\ndefence of her darling. It was the end of the fourth day when Mr. Vincy\r\nsaid to her\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, Lucy, my dear, don\xe2\x80\x99t be so down-hearted. You always have spoiled\r\nthe boy, and you must go on spoiling him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing ever did cut me so before, Vincy,\xe2\x80\x9d said the wife, her fair\r\nthroat and chin beginning to tremble again, \xe2\x80\x9conly his illness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPooh, pooh, never mind! We must expect to have trouble with our\r\nchildren. Don\xe2\x80\x99t make it worse by letting me see you out of spirits.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I won\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Vincy, roused by this appeal and adjusting\r\nherself with a little shake as of a bird which lays down its ruffled\r\nplumage.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt won\xe2\x80\x99t do to begin making a fuss about one,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Vincy, wishing\r\nto combine a little grumbling with domestic cheerfulness. \xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nRosamond as well as Fred.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, poor thing. I\xe2\x80\x99m sure I felt for her being disappointed of her\r\nbaby; but she got over it nicely.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBaby, pooh! I can see Lydgate is making a mess of his practice, and\r\ngetting into debt too, by what I hear. I shall have Rosamond coming to\r\nme with a pretty tale one of these days. But they\xe2\x80\x99ll get no money from\r\nme, I know. Let _his_ family help him. I never did like that marriage.\r\nBut it\xe2\x80\x99s no use talking. Ring the bell for lemons, and don\xe2\x80\x99t look dull\r\nany more, Lucy. I\xe2\x80\x99ll drive you and Louisa to Riverston to-morrow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER LVII.\r\n\r\nThey numbered scarce eight summers when a name\r\n    Rose on their souls and stirred such motions there\r\nAs thrill the buds and shape their hidden frame\r\n    At penetration of the quickening air:\r\nHis name who told of loyal Evan Dhu,\r\n    Of quaint Bradwardine, and Vich Ian Vor,\r\nMaking the little world their childhood knew\r\n    Large with a land of mountain lake and scaur,\r\nAnd larger yet with wonder, love, belief\r\n    Toward Walter Scott who living far away\r\nSent them this wealth of joy and noble grief.\r\n    The book and they must part, but day by day,\r\n        In lines that thwart like portly spiders ran\r\n        They wrote the tale, from Tully Veolan.\r\n\r\n\r\nThe evening that Fred Vincy walked to Lowick parsonage (he had begun to\r\nsee that this was a world in which even a spirited young man must\r\nsometimes walk for want of a horse to carry him) he set out at five\r\no\xe2\x80\x99clock and called on Mrs. Garth by the way, wishing to assure himself\r\nthat she accepted their new relations willingly.\r\n\r\nHe found the family group, dogs and cats included, under the great\r\napple-tree in the orchard. It was a festival with Mrs. Garth, for her\r\neldest son, Christy, her peculiar joy and pride, had come home for a\r\nshort holiday\xe2\x80\x94Christy, who held it the most desirable thing in the\r\nworld to be a tutor, to study all literatures and be a regenerate\r\nPorson, and who was an incorporate criticism on poor Fred, a sort of\r\nobject-lesson given to him by the educational mother. Christy himself,\r\na square-browed, broad-shouldered masculine edition of his mother not\r\nmuch higher than Fred\xe2\x80\x99s shoulder\xe2\x80\x94which made it the harder that he\r\nshould be held superior\xe2\x80\x94was always as simple as possible, and thought\r\nno more of Fred\xe2\x80\x99s disinclination to scholarship than of a giraffe\xe2\x80\x99s,\r\nwishing that he himself were more of the same height. He was lying on\r\nthe ground now by his mother\xe2\x80\x99s chair, with his straw hat laid flat over\r\nhis eyes, while Jim on the other side was reading aloud from that\r\nbeloved writer who has made a chief part in the happiness of many young\r\nlives. The volume was \xe2\x80\x9cIvanhoe,\xe2\x80\x9d and Jim was in the great archery scene\r\nat the tournament, but suffered much interruption from Ben, who had\r\nfetched his own old bow and arrows, and was making himself dreadfully\r\ndisagreeable, Letty thought, by begging all present to observe his\r\nrandom shots, which no one wished to do except Brownie, the\r\nactive-minded but probably shallow mongrel, while the grizzled\r\nNewfoundland lying in the sun looked on with the dull-eyed neutrality\r\nof extreme old age. Letty herself, showing as to her mouth and pinafore\r\nsome slight signs that she had been assisting at the gathering of the\r\ncherries which stood in a coral-heap on the tea-table, was now seated\r\non the grass, listening open-eyed to the reading.\r\n\r\nBut the centre of interest was changed for all by the arrival of Fred\r\nVincy. When, seating himself on a garden-stool, he said that he was on\r\nhis way to Lowick Parsonage, Ben, who had thrown down his bow, and\r\nsnatched up a reluctant half-grown kitten instead, strode across Fred\xe2\x80\x99s\r\noutstretched leg, and said \xe2\x80\x9cTake me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, and me too,\xe2\x80\x9d said Letty.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou can\xe2\x80\x99t keep up with Fred and me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I can. Mother, please say that I am to go,\xe2\x80\x9d urged Letty, whose\r\nlife was much checkered by resistance to her depreciation as a girl.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shall stay with Christy,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Jim; as much as to say that he\r\nhad the advantage of those simpletons; whereupon Letty put her hand up\r\nto her head and looked with jealous indecision from the one to the\r\nother.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us all go and see Mary,\xe2\x80\x9d said Christy, opening his arms.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, my dear child, we must not go in a swarm to the parsonage. And\r\nthat old Glasgow suit of yours would never do. Besides, your father\r\nwill come home. We must let Fred go alone. He can tell Mary that you\r\nare here, and she will come back to-morrow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nChristy glanced at his own threadbare knees, and then at Fred\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nbeautiful white trousers. Certainly Fred\xe2\x80\x99s tailoring suggested the\r\nadvantages of an English university, and he had a graceful way even of\r\nlooking warm and of pushing his hair back with his handkerchief.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cChildren, run away,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Garth; \xe2\x80\x9cit is too warm to hang about\r\nyour friends. Take your brother and show him the rabbits.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe eldest understood, and led off the children immediately. Fred felt\r\nthat Mrs. Garth wished to give him an opportunity of saying anything he\r\nhad to say, but he could only begin by observing\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow glad you must be to have Christy here!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; he has come sooner than I expected. He got down from the coach at\r\nnine o\xe2\x80\x99clock, just after his father went out. I am longing for Caleb to\r\ncome and hear what wonderful progress Christy is making. He has paid\r\nhis expenses for the last year by giving lessons, carrying on hard\r\nstudy at the same time. He hopes soon to get a private tutorship and go\r\nabroad.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is a great fellow,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fred, to whom these cheerful truths had a\r\nmedicinal taste, \xe2\x80\x9cand no trouble to anybody.\xe2\x80\x9d After a slight pause, he\r\nadded, \xe2\x80\x9cBut I fear you will think that I am going to be a great deal of\r\ntrouble to Mr. Garth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCaleb likes taking trouble: he is one of those men who always do more\r\nthan any one would have thought of asking them to do,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Mrs.\r\nGarth. She was knitting, and could either look at Fred or not, as she\r\nchose\xe2\x80\x94always an advantage when one is bent on loading speech with\r\nsalutary meaning; and though Mrs. Garth intended to be duly reserved,\r\nshe did wish to say something that Fred might be the better for.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know you think me very undeserving, Mrs. Garth, and with good\r\nreason,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fred, his spirit rising a little at the perception of\r\nsomething like a disposition to lecture him. \xe2\x80\x9cI happen to have behaved\r\njust the worst to the people I can\xe2\x80\x99t help wishing for the most from.\r\nBut while two men like Mr. Garth and Mr. Farebrother have not given me\r\nup, I don\xe2\x80\x99t see why I should give myself up.\xe2\x80\x9d Fred thought it might be\r\nwell to suggest these masculine examples to Mrs. Garth.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAssuredly,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, with gathering emphasis. \xe2\x80\x9cA young man for whom\r\ntwo such elders had devoted themselves would indeed be culpable if he\r\nthrew himself away and made their sacrifices vain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFred wondered a little at this strong language, but only said, \xe2\x80\x9cI hope\r\nit will not be so with me, Mrs. Garth, since I have some encouragement\r\nto believe that I may win Mary. Mr. Garth has told you about that? You\r\nwere not surprised, I dare say?\xe2\x80\x9d Fred ended, innocently referring only\r\nto his own love as probably evident enough.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot surprised that Mary has given you encouragement?\xe2\x80\x9d returned Mrs.\r\nGarth, who thought it would be well for Fred to be more alive to the\r\nfact that Mary\xe2\x80\x99s friends could not possibly have wished this\r\nbeforehand, whatever the Vincys might suppose. \xe2\x80\x9cYes, I confess I was\r\nsurprised.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe never did give me any\xe2\x80\x94not the least in the world, when I talked to\r\nher myself,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fred, eager to vindicate Mary. \xe2\x80\x9cBut when I asked Mr.\r\nFarebrother to speak for me, she allowed him to tell me there was a\r\nhope.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe power of admonition which had begun to stir in Mrs. Garth had not\r\nyet discharged itself. It was a little too provoking even for _her_\r\nself-control that this blooming youngster should flourish on the\r\ndisappointments of sadder and wiser people\xe2\x80\x94making a meal of a\r\nnightingale and never knowing it\xe2\x80\x94and that all the while his family\r\nshould suppose that hers was in eager need of this sprig; and her\r\nvexation had fermented the more actively because of its total\r\nrepression towards her husband. Exemplary wives will sometimes find\r\nscapegoats in this way. She now said with energetic decision, \xe2\x80\x9cYou made\r\na great mistake, Fred, in asking Mr. Farebrother to speak for you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid I?\xe2\x80\x9d said Fred, reddening instantaneously. He was alarmed, but at a\r\nloss to know what Mrs. Garth meant, and added, in an apologetic tone,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Farebrother has always been such a friend of ours; and Mary, I\r\nknew, would listen to him gravely; and he took it on himself quite\r\nreadily.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, young people are usually blind to everything but their own\r\nwishes, and seldom imagine how much those wishes cost others,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nMrs. Garth. She did not mean to go beyond this salutary general\r\ndoctrine, and threw her indignation into a needless unwinding of her\r\nworsted, knitting her brow at it with a grand air.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI cannot conceive how it could be any pain to Mr. Farebrother,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nFred, who nevertheless felt that surprising conceptions were beginning\r\nto form themselves.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPrecisely; you cannot conceive,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Garth, cutting her words as\r\nneatly as possible.\r\n\r\nFor a moment Fred looked at the horizon with a dismayed anxiety, and\r\nthen turning with a quick movement said almost sharply\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you mean to say, Mrs. Garth, that Mr. Farebrother is in love with\r\nMary?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd if it were so, Fred, I think you are the last person who ought to\r\nbe surprised,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Mrs. Garth, laying her knitting down beside her\r\nand folding her arms. It was an unwonted sign of emotion in her that\r\nshe should put her work out of her hands. In fact her feelings were\r\ndivided between the satisfaction of giving Fred his discipline and the\r\nsense of having gone a little too far. Fred took his hat and stick and\r\nrose quickly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you think I am standing in his way, and in Mary\xe2\x80\x99s too?\xe2\x80\x9d he said,\r\nin a tone which seemed to demand an answer.\r\n\r\nMrs. Garth could not speak immediately. She had brought herself into\r\nthe unpleasant position of being called on to say what she really felt,\r\nyet what she knew there were strong reasons for concealing. And to her\r\nthe consciousness of having exceeded in words was peculiarly\r\nmortifying. Besides, Fred had given out unexpected electricity, and he\r\nnow added, \xe2\x80\x9cMr. Garth seemed pleased that Mary should be attached to\r\nme. He could not have known anything of this.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Garth felt a severe twinge at this mention of her husband, the\r\nfear that Caleb might think her in the wrong not being easily\r\nendurable. She answered, wanting to check unintended consequences\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI spoke from inference only. I am not aware that Mary knows anything\r\nof the matter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut she hesitated to beg that he would keep entire silence on a subject\r\nwhich she had herself unnecessarily mentioned, not being used to stoop\r\nin that way; and while she was hesitating there was already a rush of\r\nunintended consequences under the apple-tree where the tea-things\r\nstood. Ben, bouncing across the grass with Brownie at his heels, and\r\nseeing the kitten dragging the knitting by a lengthening line of wool,\r\nshouted and clapped his hands; Brownie barked, the kitten, desperate,\r\njumped on the tea-table and upset the milk, then jumped down again and\r\nswept half the cherries with it; and Ben, snatching up the half-knitted\r\nsock-top, fitted it over the kitten\xe2\x80\x99s head as a new source of madness,\r\nwhile Letty arriving cried out to her mother against this cruelty\xe2\x80\x94it\r\nwas a history as full of sensation as \xe2\x80\x9cThis is the house that Jack\r\nbuilt.\xe2\x80\x9d Mrs. Garth was obliged to interfere, the other young ones came\r\nup and the _t\xc3\xaate-\xc3\xa0-t\xc3\xaate_ with Fred was ended. He got away as soon as he\r\ncould, and Mrs. Garth could only imply some retractation of her\r\nseverity by saying \xe2\x80\x9cGod bless you\xe2\x80\x9d when she shook hands with him.\r\n\r\nShe was unpleasantly conscious that she had been on the verge of\r\nspeaking as \xe2\x80\x9cone of the foolish women speaketh\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94telling first and\r\nentreating silence after. But she had not entreated silence, and to\r\nprevent Caleb\xe2\x80\x99s blame she determined to blame herself and confess all\r\nto him that very night. It was curious what an awful tribunal the mild\r\nCaleb\xe2\x80\x99s was to her, whenever he set it up. But she meant to point out\r\nto him that the revelation might do Fred Vincy a great deal of good.\r\n\r\nNo doubt it was having a strong effect on him as he walked to Lowick.\r\nFred\xe2\x80\x99s light hopeful nature had perhaps never had so much of a bruise\r\nas from this suggestion that if he had been out of the way Mary might\r\nhave made a thoroughly good match. Also he was piqued that he had been\r\nwhat he called such a stupid lout as to ask that intervention from Mr.\r\nFarebrother. But it was not in a lover\xe2\x80\x99s nature\xe2\x80\x94it was not in Fred\xe2\x80\x99s,\r\nthat the new anxiety raised about Mary\xe2\x80\x99s feeling should not surmount\r\nevery other. Notwithstanding his trust in Mr. Farebrother\xe2\x80\x99s generosity,\r\nnotwithstanding what Mary had said to him, Fred could not help feeling\r\nthat he had a rival: it was a new consciousness, and he objected to it\r\nextremely, not being in the least ready to give up Mary for her good,\r\nbeing ready rather to fight for her with any man whatsoever. But the\r\nfighting with Mr. Farebrother must be of a metaphorical kind, which was\r\nmuch more difficult to Fred than the muscular. Certainly this\r\nexperience was a discipline for Fred hardly less sharp than his\r\ndisappointment about his uncle\xe2\x80\x99s will. The iron had not entered into\r\nhis soul, but he had begun to imagine what the sharp edge would be. It\r\ndid not once occur to Fred that Mrs. Garth might be mistaken about Mr.\r\nFarebrother, but he suspected that she might be wrong about Mary. Mary\r\nhad been staying at the parsonage lately, and her mother might know\r\nvery little of what had been passing in her mind.\r\n\r\nHe did not feel easier when he found her looking cheerful with the\r\nthree ladies in the drawing-room. They were in animated discussion on\r\nsome subject which was dropped when he entered, and Mary was copying\r\nthe labels from a heap of shallow cabinet drawers, in a minute\r\nhandwriting which she was skilled in. Mr. Farebrother was somewhere in\r\nthe village, and the three ladies knew nothing of Fred\xe2\x80\x99s peculiar\r\nrelation to Mary: it was impossible for either of them to propose that\r\nthey should walk round the garden, and Fred predicted to himself that\r\nhe should have to go away without saying a word to her in private. He\r\ntold her first of Christy\xe2\x80\x99s arrival and then of his own engagement with\r\nher father; and he was comforted by seeing that this latter news\r\ntouched her keenly. She said hurriedly, \xe2\x80\x9cI am so glad,\xe2\x80\x9d and then bent\r\nover her writing to hinder any one from noticing her face. But here was\r\na subject which Mrs. Farebrother could not let pass.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t mean, my dear Miss Garth, that you are glad to hear of a\r\nyoung man giving up the Church for which he was educated: you only mean\r\nthat things being so, you are glad that he should be under an excellent\r\nman like your father.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, really, Mrs. Farebrother, I am glad of both, I fear,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mary,\r\ncleverly getting rid of one rebellious tear. \xe2\x80\x9cI have a dreadfully\r\nsecular mind. I never liked any clergyman except the Vicar of Wakefield\r\nand Mr. Farebrother.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow why, my dear?\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Farebrother, pausing on her large wooden\r\nknitting-needles and looking at Mary. \xe2\x80\x9cYou have always a good reason\r\nfor your opinions, but this astonishes me. Of course I put out of the\r\nquestion those who preach new doctrine. But why should you dislike\r\nclergymen?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh dear,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mary, her face breaking into merriment as she seemed to\r\nconsider a moment, \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t like their neckcloths.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, you don\xe2\x80\x99t like Camden\xe2\x80\x99s, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Winifred, in some\r\nanxiety.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I do,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mary. \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t like the other clergymen\xe2\x80\x99s neckcloths,\r\nbecause it is they who wear them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow very puzzling!\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Noble, feeling that her own intellect\r\nwas probably deficient.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear, you are joking. You would have better reasons than these for\r\nslighting so respectable a class of men,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Farebrother,\r\nmajestically.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMiss Garth has such severe notions of what people should be that it is\r\ndifficult to satisfy her,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fred.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I am glad at least that she makes an exception in favor of my\r\nson,\xe2\x80\x9d said the old lady.\r\n\r\nMary was wondering at Fred\xe2\x80\x99s piqued tone, when Mr. Farebrother came in\r\nand had to hear the news about the engagement under Mr. Garth. At the\r\nend he said with quiet satisfaction, \xe2\x80\x9c_That_ is right;\xe2\x80\x9d and then bent\r\nto look at Mary\xe2\x80\x99s labels and praise her handwriting. Fred felt horribly\r\njealous\xe2\x80\x94was glad, of course, that Mr. Farebrother was so estimable, but\r\nwished that he had been ugly and fat as men at forty sometimes are. It\r\nwas clear what the end would be, since Mary openly placed Farebrother\r\nabove everybody, and these women were all evidently encouraging the\r\naffair. He was feeling sure that he should have no chance of speaking\r\nto Mary, when Mr. Farebrother said\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFred, help me to carry these drawers back into my study\xe2\x80\x94you have never\r\nseen my fine new study. Pray come too, Miss Garth. I want you to see a\r\nstupendous spider I found this morning.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMary at once saw the Vicar\xe2\x80\x99s intention. He had never since the\r\nmemorable evening deviated from his old pastoral kindness towards her,\r\nand her momentary wonder and doubt had quite gone to sleep. Mary was\r\naccustomed to think rather rigorously of what was probable, and if a\r\nbelief flattered her vanity she felt warned to dismiss it as\r\nridiculous, having early had much exercise in such dismissals. It was\r\nas she had foreseen: when Fred had been asked to admire the fittings of\r\nthe study, and she had been asked to admire the spider, Mr. Farebrother\r\nsaid\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWait here a minute or two. I am going to look out an engraving which\r\nFred is tall enough to hang for me. I shall be back in a few minutes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nAnd then he went out. Nevertheless, the first word Fred said to Mary\r\nwas\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is of no use, whatever I do, Mary. You are sure to marry\r\nFarebrother at last.\xe2\x80\x9d There was some rage in his tone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you mean, Fred?\xe2\x80\x9d Mary exclaimed indignantly, blushing deeply,\r\nand surprised out of all her readiness in reply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is impossible that you should not see it all clearly enough\xe2\x80\x94you who\r\nsee everything.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI only see that you are behaving very ill, Fred, in speaking so of Mr.\r\nFarebrother after he has pleaded your cause in every way. How can you\r\nhave taken up such an idea?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFred was rather deep, in spite of his irritation. If Mary had really\r\nbeen unsuspicious, there was no good in telling her what Mrs. Garth had\r\nsaid.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt follows as a matter of course,\xe2\x80\x9d he replied. \xe2\x80\x9cWhen you are\r\ncontinually seeing a man who beats me in everything, and whom you set\r\nup above everybody, I can have no fair chance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are very ungrateful, Fred,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mary. \xe2\x80\x9cI wish I had never told\r\nMr. Farebrother that I cared for you in the least.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I am not ungrateful; I should be the happiest fellow in the world\r\nif it were not for this. I told your father everything, and he was very\r\nkind; he treated me as if I were his son. I could go at the work with a\r\nwill, writing and everything, if it were not for this.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor this? for what?\xe2\x80\x9d said Mary, imagining now that something specific\r\nmust have been said or done.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis dreadful certainty that I shall be bowled out by Farebrother.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nMary was appeased by her inclination to laugh.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFred,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, peeping round to catch his eyes, which were sulkily\r\nturned away from her, \xe2\x80\x9cyou are too delightfully ridiculous. If you were\r\nnot such a charming simpleton, what a temptation this would be to play\r\nthe wicked coquette, and let you suppose that somebody besides you has\r\nmade love to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you really like me best, Mary?\xe2\x80\x9d said Fred, turning eyes full of\r\naffection on her, and trying to take her hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t like you at all at this moment,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mary, retreating, and\r\nputting her hands behind her. \xe2\x80\x9cI only said that no mortal ever made\r\nlove to me besides you.
